**Belgrade** ^[\[b\]](#cite_note-11)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Serbia "List of cities in Serbia") of [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"). It is located at the [confluence](/wiki/Confluence "Confluence") of the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") and [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") rivers and at the crossroads of the [Pannonian Plain](/wiki/Pannonian_Basin "Pannonian Basin") and the [Balkan Peninsula](/wiki/Balkan_Peninsula "Balkan Peninsula").^[\[10\]](#cite_note-city_of_belgrade-2-12)^ The population of the Belgrade metropolitan area is 1,685,563 according to the 2022 census.^[\[4\]](#cite_note-statgovrs-4)^ It is one of the [major cities of Southeast Europe](/wiki/Balkans#Urbanization "Balkans") and the [third most populous city on the Danube river](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_on_Danube_river "List of cities and towns on Danube river").{#cite_ref-statgovrs_4-1}

Belgrade is one of the [oldest continuously inhabited cities in Europe](/wiki/List_of_oldest_continuously_inhabited_cities "List of oldest continuously inhabited cities") and the world. One of the most important prehistoric cultures of [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), the [Vinča culture](/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da_culture "Vinča culture"), evolved within the Belgrade area in the 6th millennium BC. In antiquity, [Thraco](/wiki/Thracians "Thracians")-[Dacians](/wiki/Dacians "Dacians") inhabited the region and, after 279 BC, [Celts](/wiki/Celts "Celts") settled the city, naming it *[Singidūn](/wiki/Singidunum "Singidunum")* .^[\[11\]](#cite_note-city_of_belgrade-3-13)^ It was [conquered by the Romans](/wiki/Roman_Serbia "Roman Serbia") under the reign of [Augustus](/wiki/Augustus "Augustus") and awarded Roman [city rights](/wiki/Town_privileges "Town privileges") in the mid-2nd century.^[\[12\]](#cite_note-rich-1992-14)^ It was settled by the [Slavs](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") in the 520s, and changed hands several times between the [Byzantine Empire](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire"), the [Frankish Empire](/wiki/Frankish_Empire "Frankish Empire"), the [Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire "First Bulgarian Empire"), and the [Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary") before it became the seat of the [Serbian king](/wiki/List_of_Serbian_monarchs "List of Serbian monarchs") [Stefan Dragutin](/wiki/Stefan_Dragutin_of_Serbia "Stefan Dragutin of Serbia") in 1284. Belgrade served as capital of the [Serbian Despotate](/wiki/Serbian_Despotate "Serbian Despotate") during the reign of [Stefan Lazarević](/wiki/Stefan_Lazarevi%C4%87 "Stefan Lazarević"), and then his successor [Đurađ Branković](/wiki/%C4%90ura%C4%91_Brankovi%C4%87 "Đurađ Branković") returned it to the Hungarian king in 1427. Noon bells in support of the Hungarian army against the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") during the [siege in 1456](/wiki/Siege_of_Belgrade_(1456) "Siege of Belgrade (1456)") have remained a widespread church tradition to this day. In 1521, Belgrade was conquered by the Ottomans and became the seat of the [Sanjak of Smederevo](/wiki/Sanjak_of_Smederevo "Sanjak of Smederevo").^[\[13\]](#cite_note-15)^ It frequently passed from Ottoman to [Habsburg](/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy "Habsburg monarchy") rule, which saw the destruction of most of the city during the [Ottoman--Habsburg wars](/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Habsburg_wars "Ottoman–Habsburg wars").{#cite_ref-15}

Following the [Serbian Revolution](/wiki/Serbian_Revolution "Serbian Revolution"), Belgrade was once again named the capital of Serbia in 1841. [Northern Belgrade](/wiki/Zemun "Zemun") remained the southernmost [Habsburg](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") post until 1918, when it was attached to the city, due to former Austro-Hungarian territories becoming part of the new [Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats_and_Slovenes "Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes") after [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"). Belgrade was the capital of [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia "Yugoslavia") from its [creation](/wiki/Creation_of_Yugoslavia "Creation of Yugoslavia") to its dissolution.^[\[note 1\]](#cite_note-16)^ In a fatally strategic position, the city has been battled over in 115 wars and razed 44 times, being bombed five times and besieged many times.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-nurden-2009-17)^{#cite_ref-nurden-2009_17-0}

Being Serbia's [primate city](/wiki/Primate_city "Primate city"), Belgrade has special [administrative status](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Serbia "Administrative divisions of Serbia") within Serbia.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-city_of_belgrade-18)^ It is the seat of the central government, administrative bodies, and government ministries, as well as home to almost all of the largest Serbian companies, media, and scientific institutions. Belgrade is classified as a Beta-[Global City](/wiki/Global_city "Global city").^[\[16\]](#cite_note-19)^ The city is home to the [University Clinical Centre of Serbia](/wiki/Clinical_Centre_of_Serbia "Clinical Centre of Serbia"), a hospital complex with one of the [largest capacities in the world](/wiki/List_of_hospitals_by_capacity "List of hospitals by capacity"); the [Church of Saint Sava](/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Sava "Church of Saint Sava"), one of the [largest Orthodox church buildings](/wiki/List_of_largest_Eastern_Orthodox_church_buildings "List of largest Eastern Orthodox church buildings"); and the [Belgrade Arena](/wiki/Belgrade_Arena "Belgrade Arena"), one of the [largest capacity indoor arenas in Europe](/wiki/List_of_indoor_arenas_in_Europe "List of indoor arenas in Europe").{#cite_ref-19}

Belgrade hosted major international events such as the [Danube River Conference of 1948](/wiki/Danube_River_Conference_of_1948 "Danube River Conference of 1948"), the first [Non-Aligned Movement Summit](/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement_Summit "Non-Aligned Movement Summit") (1961), the first major gathering of the [OSCE](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe "Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe") (1977--1978), the [Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest "Eurovision Song Contest") ([2008](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2008 "Eurovision Song Contest 2008")), as well as sports events such as the first [FINA World Aquatics Championships](/wiki/FINA_World_Aquatics_Championships "FINA World Aquatics Championships") ([1973](/wiki/1973_World_Aquatics_Championships "1973 World Aquatics Championships")), [UEFA Euro](/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship "UEFA European Championship") ([1976](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1976 "UEFA Euro 1976")), [Summer Universiade](/wiki/Universiade "Universiade") ([2009](/wiki/2009_Summer_Universiade "2009 Summer Universiade")) and [EuroBasket](/wiki/EuroBasket "EuroBasket") three times ([1961](/wiki/EuroBasket_1961 "EuroBasket 1961"), [1975](/wiki/EuroBasket_1975 "EuroBasket 1975"), [2005](/wiki/EuroBasket_2005 "EuroBasket 2005")). On 21 June 2023, Belgrade was confirmed host of the BIE- Specialized Exhibition [Expo 2027](/wiki/Expo_2027 "Expo 2027").^[\[17\]](#cite_note-20)^{#cite_ref-20}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Belgrade](/wiki/History_of_Belgrade "History of Belgrade")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Belgrade](/wiki/Timeline_of_Belgrade "Timeline of Belgrade").  

### Prehistory {#Prehistory}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Prehistory")\]  
See also: [Prehistoric sites in Serbia](/wiki/Prehistoric_sites_in_Serbia "Prehistoric sites in Serbia") and [Prehistory of Southeastern Europe](/wiki/Prehistory_of_Southeastern_Europe "Prehistory of Southeastern Europe")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg/150px-Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg) [Vinča culture](/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da_culture "Vinča culture") figurine, 4000--4500 BC.

[Chipped stone tools](/wiki/Lithic_reduction "Lithic reduction") found in [Zemun](/wiki/Zemun "Zemun") show that the area around Belgrade was inhabited by [nomadic foragers](/wiki/Hunter-gatherer "Hunter-gatherer") in the [Palaeolithic](/wiki/Palaeolithic "Palaeolithic") and [Mesolithic](/wiki/Mesolithic "Mesolithic") eras. Some of these tools are of [Mousterian industry](/wiki/Mousterian "Mousterian")---belonging to [Neanderthals](/wiki/Neanderthals "Neanderthals") rather than modern humans. [Aurignacian](/wiki/Aurignacian "Aurignacian") and [Gravettian](/wiki/Gravettian "Gravettian") tools have also been discovered near the area, indicating some settlement between 50,000 and 20,000 years ago.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-21)^ The first farming people to settle in the region are associated with the [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") [Starčevo culture](/wiki/Star%C4%8Devo_culture "Starčevo culture"), which flourished between 6200 and 5200 BC.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-22)^ There are several Starčevo sites in and around Belgrade, including the eponymous site of [Starčevo](/wiki/Star%C4%8Devo "Starčevo"). The Starčevo culture was succeeded by the [Vinča culture](/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da_culture "Vinča culture") (5500--4500 BC), a more sophisticated farming culture that grew out of the earlier Starčevo settlements and also named for a site in the Belgrade region ([Vinča-Belo Brdo](/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da-Belo_Brdo "Vinča-Belo Brdo")). The Vinča culture is known for its very large settlements, one of the earliest [settlements by continuous habitation](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_time_of_continuous_habitation "List of cities by time of continuous habitation") and some of the largest in prehistoric Europe.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-23)^ Also associated with the Vinča culture are anthropomorphic figurines such as the [Lady of Vinča](/wiki/Lady_of_Vin%C4%8Da "Lady of Vinča"), the earliest known [copper metallurgy](/wiki/Copper_Age "Copper Age") in Europe,^[\[21\]](#cite_note-24)^ and a [proto-writing](/wiki/Proto-writing "Proto-writing") form developed prior to the [Sumerians](/wiki/Sumer "Sumer") and [Minoans](/wiki/Minoans "Minoans") known as the [Old European script](/wiki/Old_European_script "Old European script"), which dates back to around 5300 BC.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-25)^ Within the city proper, on Cetinjska Street, a skull of a Paleolithic human dated to before 5000 BC was discovered in 1890.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-26)^{#cite_ref-26}  

### Antiquity {#Antiquity}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Antiquity")\]  
See also: [Serbia in the Roman era](/wiki/Serbia_in_the_Roman_era "Serbia in the Roman era")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Guardian_of_the_city.jpg/290px-Guardian_of_the_city.jpg)](/wiki/File:Guardian_of_the_city.jpg) [Belgrade Fortress](/wiki/Belgrade_Fortress "Belgrade Fortress"), built during a long period of time from the 2nd to the 18th century, located on the confluence of the two rivers Sava and [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube")

Evidence of early knowledge about Belgrade's geographical location comes from a variety of ancient myths and legends. The ridge overlooking the confluence of the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") and [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") rivers, for example, has been identified as one of the places in the story of [Jason](/wiki/Jason "Jason") and the [Argonauts](/wiki/Argonauts "Argonauts").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-27)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-28)^ In the time of antiquity, too, the area was populated by [Paleo-Balkan tribes](/wiki/Prehistory_of_Southeastern_Europe "Prehistory of Southeastern Europe"), including the [Thracians](/wiki/Thracians "Thracians") and the [Dacians](/wiki/Dacians "Dacians"), who ruled much of Belgrade's surroundings.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-29)^ Specifically, Belgrade was at one point inhabited by the Thraco-Dacian tribe Singi;^[\[11\]](#cite_note-city_of_belgrade-3-13)^ following [Celtic invasion](/wiki/Gallic_invasion_of_Balkans "Gallic invasion of Balkans") in 279 BC, the [Scordisci](/wiki/Scordisci "Scordisci") wrested the city from their hands, naming it *Singidūn* (*d\|ūn* , fortress).^[\[11\]](#cite_note-city_of_belgrade-3-13)^ In 34--33 BC, the Roman army reached Belgrade. It became the [romanised](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") *[Singidunum](/wiki/Singidunum "Singidunum")* in the 1st century AD and, by the mid-2nd century, the city was proclaimed a *[municipium](/wiki/Municipium "Municipium")* by the Roman authorities, evolving into a full-fledged *[colonia](/wiki/Colonia_(Roman) "Colonia (Roman)")* (the highest city class) by the end of the century.^[\[12\]](#cite_note-rich-1992-14)^ While the first Christian [Emperor of Rome](/wiki/Roman_Emperor "Roman Emperor")---[Constantine I](/wiki/Constantine_I "Constantine I"), also known as [Constantine the Great](/wiki/Constantine_the_Great "Constantine the Great")^[\[27\]](#cite_note-30)^---was born in the territory of [Naissus](/wiki/Naissus "Naissus") to the city's south, Roman Christianity's champion, Flavius Iovianus (Jovian/Jovan), was born in Singidunum.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-31)^ Jovian reestablished Christianity as the official religion of the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"), ending the brief revival of [traditional Roman religions](/wiki/Religion_in_ancient_Rome "Religion in ancient Rome") under his predecessor [Julian the Apostate](/wiki/Julian_the_Apostate "Julian the Apostate"). In 395 AD, the site passed to the Eastern Roman or [Byzantine Empire](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire").^[\[29\]](#cite_note-32)^ Across the Sava from Singidunum was the Celtic city of [Taurunum (Zemun)](/wiki/Zemun "Zemun"); the two were connected with a bridge throughout Roman and Byzantine times.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-33)^{#cite_ref-33}  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]  
See also: [Serbia in the Middle Ages](/wiki/Serbia_in_the_Middle_Ages "Serbia in the Middle Ages")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Bellgrad-Weissenburg_1400.jpg/220px-Bellgrad-Weissenburg_1400.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bellgrad-Weissenburg_1400.jpg) Belgrade 1400, before ottoman occupation.

In 442, the area was ravaged by [Attila the Hun](/wiki/Attila_the_Hun "Attila the Hun").^[\[31\]](#cite_note-34)^ In 471, it was taken by [Theodoric the Great](/wiki/Theodoric_the_Great "Theodoric the Great"), king of the Ostrogoths, who continued into Italy.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-35)^ As the [Ostrogoths](/wiki/Ostrogoths "Ostrogoths") left, another Germanic tribe, the [Gepids](/wiki/Gepids "Gepids"), invaded the city. In 539, it was retaken by the Byzantines.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-36)^ In 577, some 100,000 Slavs poured into [Thrace](/wiki/Thrace "Thrace") and [Illyricum](/wiki/Illyricum_(Roman_province) "Illyricum (Roman province)"), pillaging cities and more permanently settling the region. ^[\[34\]](#cite_note-37)^{#cite_ref-37}

The [Avars](/wiki/Avars_(Carpathians) "Avars (Carpathians)"), under [Bayan I](/wiki/Bayan_I "Bayan I"), conquered the whole region and its new Slavic population by 582.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-38)^ Following Byzantine reconquest, the Byzantine chronicle *[De Administrando Imperio](/wiki/De_Administrando_Imperio "De Administrando Imperio")* mentions the [White Serbs](/wiki/White_Serbs "White Serbs"), who had stopped in Belgrade on their way back home, asking the *[strategos](/wiki/Strategos "Strategos")* for lands; they received provinces in the west, towards the Adriatic, which they would rule as subjects to [Heraclius](/wiki/Heraclius "Heraclius") (610--641).^[\[36\]](#cite_note-39)^ In 829, [Khan Omurtag](/wiki/Khan_Omurtag "Khan Omurtag") was able to add Singidunum and its environs to the First Bulgarian Empire.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-40)^^[\[38\]](#cite_note-41)^ The first record of the name *Belograd* appeared on April, 16th, 878, in a Papal missive^[\[39\]](#cite_note-42)^ to [Bulgarian ruler](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire "First Bulgarian Empire") [Boris I](/wiki/Boris_I "Boris I"). This name would appear in several variants: *Alba Bulgarica* in Latin, *Griechisch Weissenburg* in High German, *Nándorfehérvár* in Hungarian, and *Castelbianco* in Venetian, among other names, all variations of 'white fortress' or '[Bulgar](/wiki/Danube_Bulgar_Khanate "Danube Bulgar Khanate") white fortress'. For about four centuries, the city would become a battleground between the [Byzantine Empire](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire"), the medieval [Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary"), and the [Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire "First Bulgarian Empire").^[\[40\]](#cite_note-43)^ [Basil II](/wiki/Basil_II "Basil II") (976--1025) installed a garrison in Belgrade.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-44)^ The city hosted the armies of the [First](/wiki/First_Crusade "First Crusade") and the [Second Crusade](/wiki/Second_Crusade "Second Crusade"),^[\[42\]](#cite_note-beligradcom-1934-45)^ but, while passing through during the [Third Crusade](/wiki/Third_Crusade "Third Crusade"), [Frederick Barbarossa](/wiki/Frederick_Barbarossa "Frederick Barbarossa") and his 190,000 [crusaders](/wiki/Third_Crusade "Third Crusade") saw Belgrade in ruins.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-46)^{#cite_ref-46}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Panorama_i_ratna_scena_zauzimanja_Beograda_1521._god.jpg/200px-Panorama_i_ratna_scena_zauzimanja_Beograda_1521._god.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panorama_i_ratna_scena_zauzimanja_Beograda_1521._god.jpg) [Conquest of Belgrade, 1521](/wiki/Siege_of_Belgrade_(1521) "Siege of Belgrade (1521)"), Sultan [Suleiman the Magnificent](/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent "Suleiman the Magnificent") laid siege to the [Belgrade Fortress](/wiki/Belgrade_Fortress "Belgrade Fortress")

King [Stefan Dragutin](/wiki/Stefan_Dragutin_of_Serbia "Stefan Dragutin of Serbia") (r. 1276--1282) received Belgrade from his father-in-law, [Stephen V of Hungary](/wiki/Stephen_V_of_Hungary "Stephen V of Hungary"), in 1284, and it served as the capital of the [Kingdom of Syrmia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Syrmia "Kingdom of Syrmia"), a vassal state to the Kingdom of Hungary. Dragutin (Hungarian: *Dragutin István* ) is regarded as the first [Serbian king](/wiki/List_of_Serbian_monarchs "List of Serbian monarchs") to rule over Belgrade.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-4-47)^{#cite_ref-beogradrs-4_47-0}

Following the battles of [Maritsa (1371)](/wiki/Battle_of_Maritsa "Battle of Maritsa") and [Kosovo field (1389)](/wiki/Battle_of_Kosovo "Battle of Kosovo"), Moravian Serbia, to Belgrade's south, began to fall to the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire").^[\[45\]](#cite_note-48)^^[\[46\]](#cite_note-49)^{#cite_ref-49}

The northern regions of what is now Serbia persisted as the [Serbian Despotate](/wiki/Serbian_Despotate "Serbian Despotate"), with Belgrade as its capital. The city flourished under [Stefan Lazarević](/wiki/Stefan_Lazarevi%C4%87 "Stefan Lazarević"), the son of Serbian prince [Lazar Hrebeljanović](/wiki/Lazar_Hrebeljanovi%C4%87 "Lazar Hrebeljanović"). Lazarević built a castle with a citadel and towers, of which only the [Despot's tower](/wiki/Despot_Stefan_Tower "Despot Stefan Tower") and the west wall remain. He also refortified the city's ancient walls, allowing the Despotate to resist Ottoman conquest for almost 70 years. During this time, Belgrade was a haven for many Balkan peoples fleeing Ottoman rule, and is thought to have had a population ranging between 40,000 and 50,000 people.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-4-47)^{#cite_ref-beogradrs-4_47-1}

In 1427, Stefan's successor [Đurađ Branković](/wiki/%C4%90ura%C4%91_Brankovi%C4%87 "Đurađ Branković"), returning Belgrade to the [Hungarian king](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary"), made [Smederevo](/wiki/Smederevo_fortress "Smederevo fortress") his new capital. Even though the Ottomans had captured most of the [Serbian Despotate](/wiki/Serbian_Despotate "Serbian Despotate"), Belgrade, known as Nándorfehérvár in Hungarian, was [unsuccessfully besieged in 1440](/wiki/Siege_of_Belgrade_(1440) "Siege of Belgrade (1440)")^[\[42\]](#cite_note-beligradcom-1934-45)^ and 1456.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-50)^ As the city presented an obstacle to the Ottoman advance into Hungary and further, over 100,000 Ottoman soldiers^[\[48\]](#cite_note-belgradenetcom-51)^ [besieged it in 1456](/wiki/Siege_of_Belgrade_(1456) "Siege of Belgrade (1456)"), in which the Christian army led by the Hungarian General [John Hunyadi](/wiki/John_Hunyadi "John Hunyadi") successfully defended it.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-52)^ The *[noon bell](/wiki/Noon_bell "Noon bell")* ordered by [Pope Callixtus III](/wiki/Pope_Callixtus_III "Pope Callixtus III") commemorates the victory throughout the Christian world to this day, which is now a cultural symbol of [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary").^[\[42\]](#cite_note-beligradcom-1934-45)^^[\[50\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}  

### Ottoman rule and Austrian invasions {#Ottoman_rule_and_Austrian_invasions}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Ottoman rule and Austrian invasions")\]  
See also: [History of Ottoman Serbia](/wiki/History_of_Ottoman_Serbia "History of Ottoman Serbia") and [Ottoman--Habsburg wars](/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Habsburg_wars "Ottoman–Habsburg wars")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Belgrade_1684.jpg/350px-Belgrade_1684.jpg)](/wiki/File:Belgrade_1684.jpg) Belgrade in 1684

Seven decades after the initial siege, on 28 August 1521, the fort was finally captured by [Suleiman the Magnificent](/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent "Suleiman the Magnificent") with 250,000 Turkish soldiers and over 100 ships. Subsequently, most of the city was razed to the ground and its entire Orthodox Christian population was deported to [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul")^[\[42\]](#cite_note-beligradcom-1934-45)^^[\[51\]](#cite_note-54)^ to an area that has since become known as the [Belgrade forest](/wiki/Belgrade_forest "Belgrade forest").^[\[52\]](#cite_note-55)^{#cite_ref-55}

Belgrade was made the seat of the [Pashalik of Belgrade](/wiki/Pashalik_of_Belgrade "Pashalik of Belgrade") (also known as the Sanjak of Smederevo), and quickly became the second largest Ottoman town in Europe at over 100,000 people, surpassed only by [Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople").^[\[48\]](#cite_note-belgradenetcom-51)^ Ottoman rule introduced [Ottoman architecture](/wiki/Ottoman_architecture "Ottoman architecture"), including numerous mosques, and the city was resurrected---now by [Oriental](/wiki/Oriental "Oriental") influences.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-3-56)^{#cite_ref-beogradrs-3_56-0}

In 1594, a major [Serb rebellion](/wiki/Banat_Uprising "Banat Uprising") was crushed by the Ottomans. In retribution, [Grand Vizier](/wiki/Grand_vizier "Grand vizier") [Sinan Pasha](/wiki/Sinan_Pasha "Sinan Pasha") ordered the [relics](/wiki/Relic "Relic") of [Saint Sava](/wiki/Saint_Sava "Saint Sava") to be publicly torched on the [Vračar plateau](/wiki/Vra%C4%8Dar_plateau "Vračar plateau"); in the 20th century, the [church of Saint Sava](/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Sava "Church of Saint Sava") was built to commemorate this event.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-57)^{#cite_ref-57}

Occupied by the [Habsburgs](/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy "Habsburg monarchy") three times ([1688--1690](/wiki/Siege_of_Belgrade_(1688) "Siege of Belgrade (1688)"), [1717--1739](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia_(1718%E2%80%9339) "Kingdom of Serbia (1718–39)"), [1789--1791](/wiki/Siege_of_Belgrade_(1789) "Siege of Belgrade (1789)")), headed by the [Holy Roman Princes](/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire "Holy Roman Empire") [Maximilian of Bavaria](/wiki/Maximilian_II_Emanuel,_Elector_of_Bavaria "Maximilian II Emanuel, Elector of Bavaria") and [Eugene of Savoy](/wiki/Prince_Eugene_of_Savoy "Prince Eugene of Savoy"),^[\[55\]](#cite_note-58)^ and [field marshal](/wiki/Field_marshal "Field marshal") [Baron Ernst Gideon von Laudon](/wiki/Baron_Ernst_Gideon_von_Laudon "Baron Ernst Gideon von Laudon"), respectively, Belgrade was quickly recaptured by the Ottomans and substantially razed each time.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-3-56)^ During this period, the city was affected by the two [Great Serbian Migrations](/wiki/Great_Serbian_Migrations "Great Serbian Migrations"), in which hundreds of thousands of Serbs, led by two [Serbian Patriarchs](/wiki/Serbian_Patriarchs "Serbian Patriarchs"), retreated together with the Austrian soldiers into the Habsburg Empire, settling in today's [Vojvodina](/wiki/Vojvodina "Vojvodina") and [Slavonia](/wiki/Slavonia "Slavonia").^[\[56\]](#cite_note-59)^{#cite_ref-59}  

### Principality and Kingdom of Serbia {#Principality_and_Kingdom_of_Serbia}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Principality and Kingdom of Serbia")\]  
See also: [Principality of Serbia](/wiki/Principality_of_Serbia "Principality of Serbia") and [Kingdom of Serbia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia "Kingdom of Serbia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Belgrade_Cathedral_%26_Landing_Place_1.jpg/220px-Belgrade_Cathedral_%26_Landing_Place_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Belgrade_Cathedral_%26_Landing_Place_1.jpg) View of Belgrade in 1890

At the beginning of the 19th century, Belgrade was predominantly inhabited by a Muslim population. Traces of Ottoman rule and architecture---such as mosques and [bazaars](/wiki/Bazaar "Bazaar"), were to remain a prominent part of Belgrade's townscape into the 19th century; several decades, even, after Serbia was granted autonomy from the Ottoman Empire.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-60)^{#cite_ref-60}

During the [First Serbian Uprising](/wiki/First_Serbian_Uprising "First Serbian Uprising"), Serbian revolutionaries held the city from 8 January 1807 until 1813, when it was retaken by the Ottomans.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-2-61)^ In 1807, Turks in Belgrade were massacred and forcefully converted to Christianity. The massacre was encouraged by Russia in order to cement divisions between the Serb rebels and the [Porte](/wiki/Ottoman_Porte "Ottoman Porte"). Around 6,000 Muslims and Jews were forcibly converted to Christianity. Most mosques were converted into churches. Muslims, Jews, Aromanians and Greeks were subjected to forced labour, and Muslim women were widely made available to young Serb men, and some were taken into slavery. [Milenko Stojković](/wiki/Milenko_Stojkovi%C4%87 "Milenko Stojković") bought many of them, and established his harem for which he gained fame. In this circumstances Belgrade demographically transformed from Ottoman to Serb.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-AMH-62)^ After the [Second Serbian Uprising](/wiki/Second_Serbian_Uprising "Second Serbian Uprising") in 1815, Serbia achieved some sort of sovereignty, which was formally recognised by the Porte in 1830.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-63)^{#cite_ref-63}

The development of Belgrade architecture after 1815 can be divided into four periods. In the first phase, which lasted from 1815 to 1835, the dominant architectural style was still of a Balkan character, with substantial Ottoman influence. At the same time, an interest in joining the European mainstream allowed Central and Western European architecture to flourish. Between 1835 and 1850, the amount of [neoclassicist](/wiki/Neoclassicism "Neoclassicism") and [baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") buildings south of the Austrian border rose considerably, exemplified by [St Michael's Cathedral](/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Cathedral,_Belgrade "St. Michael's Cathedral, Belgrade") (Serbian: *Saborna crkva)* , completed in 1840. Between 1850 and 1875, new architecture was characterised by a turn towards the newly popular [Romanticism](/wiki/Romanticism "Romanticism"), along with older European architectural styles. Typical of Central European cities in the last quarter of the 19th century, the fourth phase was characterised by an [eclecticist](/wiki/Eclecticism "Eclecticism") style based on the Renaissance and Baroque periods.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-64)^{#cite_ref-64}

In 1841, Prince [Mihailo Obrenović](/wiki/Mihailo_Obrenovi%C4%87 "Mihailo Obrenović") moved the capital of the [Principality of Serbia](/wiki/Principality_of_Serbia "Principality of Serbia") from [Kragujevac](/wiki/Kragujevac "Kragujevac") to Belgrade.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-65)^^[\[63\]](#cite_note-66)^ During his first reign (1815--1839), Prince Miloš Obrenović pursued expansion of the city's population through the addition of new settlements, aiming and succeeding to make Belgrade the centre of the Principality's administrative, military and cultural institutions. His project of creating a new market space (the Abadžijska čaršija), however, was less successful; trade continued to be conducted in the centuries-old Donja čaršija and Gornja čaršija. Still, new construction projects were typical for the Christian quarters as the older Muslim quarters declined; from Serbia's autonomy until 1863, the number of Belgrade quarters even decreased, mainly as a consequence of the gradual [disappearance of the city's Muslim population](/wiki/Exodus_of_Muslims_from_Serbia_(1862) "Exodus of Muslims from Serbia (1862)"). An Ottoman city map from 1863 counts only 9 Muslim quarters (*mahalas* ). The names of only five such neighbourhoods are known today: Ali-pašina, Reis-efendijina, Jahja-pašina, Bajram-begova, and Laz Hadži-Mahmudova.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-67)^ Following the [Čukur Fountain incident](/wiki/%C4%8Cukur_Fountain_incident "Čukur Fountain incident"), Belgrade was bombed by the Ottomans.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-68)^{#cite_ref-68}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/De_Eerste_Balkanoorlog_1912%2C_SFA022816172.jpg/220px-De_Eerste_Balkanoorlog_1912%2C_SFA022816172.jpg)](/wiki/File:De_Eerste_Balkanoorlog_1912,_SFA022816172.jpg) Belgrade 1912

On 18 April 1867, the Ottoman government ordered the Ottoman garrison, which had been since 1826 the last representation of Ottoman suzerainty in Serbia, withdrawn from [Kalemegdan](/wiki/Kalemegdan "Kalemegdan"). The forlorn Porte's only stipulation was that the Ottoman flag continue to fly over the fortress alongside the Serbian one. Serbia's *de facto* independence dates from this event.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-69)^ In the following years, urban planner Emilijan Josimović had a significant influence on Belgrade. He conceptualised a regulation plan for the city in 1867, in which he proposed the replacement of the town's crooked streets with a [grid plan](/wiki/Grid_plan "Grid plan"). Of great importance also was the construction of independent Serbian political and cultural institutions, as well as the city's now-plentiful parks. Pointing to Josimović's work, Serbian scholars have noted an important break with Ottoman traditions. However, Istanbul---the capital city of the state to which Belgrade and Serbia *de jure* still belonged---underwent similar changes.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-70)^{#cite_ref-70}

In May 1868, *knez* Mihailo was assassinated with his cousin [Anka Konstantinović](/wiki/Anka_Konstantinovi%C4%87 "Anka Konstantinović") while riding in a carriage in his country residence.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-71)^{#cite_ref-71}

With the [Principality](/wiki/Principality_of_Serbia "Principality of Serbia")'s full independence in 1878 and its transformation into the [Kingdom of Serbia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia "Kingdom of Serbia") in 1882, Belgrade once again became a key city in the Balkans, and developed rapidly.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-2-61)^^[\[69\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-72)^ Nevertheless, conditions in Serbia remained those of an overwhelmingly agrarian country, even with the opening of a railway to [Niš](/wiki/Ni%C5%A1 "Niš"), Serbia's second city. In 1900, the capital had only 70,000 inhabitants^[\[70\]](#cite_note-73)^ (at the time Serbia numbered 2.5 million). Still, by 1905, the population had grown to more than 80,000 and, by the outbreak of World War I in 1914, it had surpassed the 100,000 citizens, disregarding [Zemun](/wiki/Zemun "Zemun"), which still belonged to [Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary").^[\[71\]](#cite_note-74)^{#cite_ref-74}

The first-ever projection of motion pictures in the Balkans and Central Europe was held in Belgrade in June 1896 by André Carr, a representative of the [Lumière brothers](/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re "Auguste and Louis Lumière"). He shot the first motion pictures of Belgrade in the next year; however, they have not been preserved.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-75)^ The first permanent cinema was opened in 1909 in Belgrade.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-76)^{#cite_ref-76}  

### World War I: Austro--German invasion {#World_War_I:_Austro.E2.80.93German_invasion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: World War I: Austro–German invasion")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Bg-7_Panorama_s_Top%C4%8Diderskog_brda_1920.jpg/900px-Bg-7_Panorama_s_Top%C4%8Diderskog_brda_1920.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bg-7_Panorama_s_Top%C4%8Diderskog_brda_1920.jpg) Belgrade seen from [Topčider](/wiki/Top%C4%8Dider "Topčider") hill in 1920.

The First World War began on 28 July 1914 when Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia. Most of the subsequent Balkan offensives occurred near Belgrade. [Austro-Hungarian](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Navy "Austro-Hungarian Navy") [monitors](/wiki/Monitor_(warship) "Monitor (warship)") shelled Belgrade on 29 July 1914, and it was taken by the [Austro-Hungarian Army](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Army "Austro-Hungarian Army") under General [Oskar Potiorek](/wiki/Oskar_Potiorek "Oskar Potiorek") on 1 December. On 16 December, it was re-taken by [Serbian troops](/wiki/Serbian_Campaign_(World_War_I) "Serbian Campaign (World War I)") under Marshal [Radomir Putnik](/wiki/Radomir_Putnik "Radomir Putnik"). After a prolonged battle which destroyed much of the city, starting on 6 October 1915, Belgrade fell to [German](/wiki/German_Army_(German_Empire) "German Army (German Empire)") and Austro-Hungarian troops commanded by Field Marshal [August von Mackensen](/wiki/August_von_Mackensen "August von Mackensen") on 9 October of the same year. The city was liberated by Serbian and [French troops](/wiki/French_Army "French Army") on 1 November 1918, under the command of Marshal [Louis Franchet d'Espèrey](/wiki/Louis_Franchet_d%27Esp%C3%A8rey "Louis Franchet d'Espèrey") of France and [Crown Prince Alexander of Serbia](/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Yugoslavia "Alexander I of Yugoslavia"). Belgrade, devastated as a front-line city, lost the title of largest city in the [Kingdom](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia") to [Subotica](/wiki/Subotica "Subotica") for some time.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-77)^{#cite_ref-77}  

### Kingdom of Yugoslavia {#Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Kingdom of Yugoslavia")\]

After the war, Belgrade became the capital of the new Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, renamed the [Kingdom of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia") in 1929. The Kingdom was split into [banovinas](/wiki/Subdivisions_of_the_Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Subdivisions of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia") and Belgrade, together with [Zemun](/wiki/Zemun "Zemun") and [Pančevo](/wiki/Pan%C4%8Devo "Pančevo"), formed a separate administrative unit.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-78)^ During this period, the city experienced fast growth and significant modernisation. Belgrade's population grew to 239,000 by 1931 (with the inclusion of Zemun), and to 320,000 by 1940. The population growth rate between 1921 and 1948 averaged 4.08% a year.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-79)^{#cite_ref-79}

In 1927, Belgrade's first airport opened, and in 1929, its first radio station began broadcasting. The [Pančevo Bridge](/wiki/Pan%C4%8Devo_Bridge "Pančevo Bridge"), which crosses the Danube, was opened in 1935,^[\[77\]](#cite_note-80)^ while [King Alexander Bridge](/wiki/King_Alexander_Bridge "King Alexander Bridge") over the Sava was opened in 1934. On 3 September 1939 the first [Belgrade Grand Prix](/wiki/Belgrade_Grand_Prix "Belgrade Grand Prix"), the last [Grand Prix motor racing](/wiki/Grand_Prix_motor_racing "Grand Prix motor racing") race before the outbreak of World War II, was held around the [Belgrade Fortress](/wiki/Belgrade_Fortress "Belgrade Fortress") and was followed by 80,000 spectators.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-81)^ The winner was [Tazio Nuvolari](/wiki/Tazio_Nuvolari "Tazio Nuvolari").^[\[79\]](#cite_note-82)^{#cite_ref-82}  

### World War II: German invasion {#World_War_II:_German_invasion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: World War II: German invasion")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Demonstracije_u_Beogradu_27._marta_1941.jpg/220px-Demonstracije_u_Beogradu_27._marta_1941.jpg)](/wiki/File:Demonstracije_u_Beogradu_27._marta_1941.jpg) People of Belgrade demonstrate their support for break-up with the [Tripartite Pact](/wiki/Tripartite_Pact "Tripartite Pact") on 27 March 1941

On 25 March 1941, the government of [regent](/wiki/Regent "Regent") [Crown Prince Paul](/wiki/Prince_Paul_of_Yugoslavia "Prince Paul of Yugoslavia") signed the [Tripartite Pact](/wiki/Tripartite_Pact "Tripartite Pact"), joining the [Axis powers](/wiki/Axis_powers_of_World_War_II "Axis powers of World War II") in an effort to stay out of the Second World War and keep Yugoslavia neutral during the conflict. This was immediately followed by mass protests in Belgrade and a military [coup d'état](/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "Coup d'état") led by Air Force commander General [Dušan Simović](/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Simovi%C4%87 "Dušan Simović"), who proclaimed [King Peter II](/wiki/Peter_II_of_Yugoslavia "Peter II of Yugoslavia") to be of age to rule the realm. As a result, the city was [heavily bombed](/wiki/Operation_Retribution_(1941) "Operation Retribution (1941)") by the [Luftwaffe](/wiki/Luftwaffe "Luftwaffe") on 6 April 1941, killing up to 2,274 people.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-83)^^[\[81\]](#cite_note-84)^^[\[82\]](#cite_note-85)^ Yugoslavia was then [invaded](/wiki/Invasion_of_Yugoslavia "Invasion of Yugoslavia") by [German](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany"), [Italian](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy "Kingdom of Italy"), [Hungarian](/wiki/Hungary_between_the_two_world_wars "Hungary between the two world wars"), and [Bulgarian](/wiki/Military_history_of_Bulgaria_during_World_War_II "Military history of Bulgaria during World War II") forces. Belgrade was captured by subterfuge, with six German soldiers led by their officer [Fritz Klingenberg](/wiki/Fritz_Klingenberg "Fritz Klingenberg") feigning threatening size, forcing the city to capitulate.{#cite_ref-85}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Bombing_of_Belgrade_1941.jpg/220px-Bombing_of_Belgrade_1941.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bombing_of_Belgrade_1941.jpg) Ruins in Belgrade after [German bombing of 1941](/wiki/Operation_Retribution_(1941) "Operation Retribution (1941)").

^[\[83\]](#cite_note-86)^ Belgrade was more directly occupied by the [German Army](/wiki/German_Army_(Wehrmacht) "German Army (Wehrmacht)") in the same month and became the seat of the puppet [Nedić regime](/wiki/Nedi%C4%87_regime "Nedić regime"), headed by its namesake general.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-87)^ Some of today's parts of Belgrade were incorporated in the [Independent State of Croatia](/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia "Independent State of Croatia") in occupied Yugoslavia, another puppet state, where [Ustashe](/wiki/Ustashe "Ustashe") regime carried out the [Genocide of Serbs](/wiki/Genocide_of_Serbs_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia "Genocide of Serbs in the Independent State of Croatia").^[\[85\]](#cite_note-88)^{#cite_ref-88}

During the summer and autumn of 1941, in reprisal for guerrilla attacks, the Germans carried out several massacres of Belgrade citizens; in particular, members of the [Jewish community](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Serbia "History of the Jews in Serbia") were subject to mass shootings at the order of General [Franz Böhme](/wiki/Franz_B%C3%B6hme "Franz Böhme"), the German [Military Governor of Serbia](/wiki/Territory_of_the_Military_Commander_in_Serbia "Territory of the Military Commander in Serbia"). Böhme rigorously enforced the rule that for every German killed, 100 Serbs or Jews would be shot.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-89)^ Belgrade became the first city in Europe to be declared by the Nazi occupation forces to be *[judenfrei](/wiki/Judenfrei "Judenfrei")* .^[\[87\]](#cite_note-90)^ The resistance movement in Belgrade was led by Major [Žarko Todorović](/wiki/%C5%BDarko_Todorovi%C4%87 "Žarko Todorović") from 1941 until his arrest in 1943.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-91)^{#cite_ref-91}

Just like [Rotterdam](/wiki/Rotterdam "Rotterdam"), which was devastated twice by both German and Allied bombing, [Belgrade was bombed](/wiki/Allied_bombing_of_Yugoslavia_in_World_War_II#1944_Easter_bombing "Allied bombing of Yugoslavia in World War II") once more during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), this time by the [Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") on 16 April 1944, killing at least 1,100 people. This bombing fell on the [Orthodox Christian](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church") [Easter](/wiki/Orthodox_Easter "Orthodox Easter").^[\[89\]](#cite_note-92)^ Most of the city remained under German occupation until 20 October 1944, when it was liberated by the [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") and the Communist [Yugoslav Partisans](/wiki/Partisans_(Yugoslavia) "Partisans (Yugoslavia)").{#cite_ref-92}

On 29 November 1945, Marshal [Josip Broz Tito](/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito "Josip Broz Tito") proclaimed the [Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Federal_People%27s_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia") in Belgrade (later renamed to [Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia") on 7 April 1963).^[\[90\]](#cite_note-93)^{#cite_ref-93}  

### Socialist Yugoslavia {#Socialist_Yugoslavia}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Socialist Yugoslavia")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Konferencija_Pokreta_nesvrstanih_1961._godine.jpg/220px-Konferencija_Pokreta_nesvrstanih_1961._godine.jpg)](/wiki/File:Konferencija_Pokreta_nesvrstanih_1961._godine.jpg) The First [Non-Aligned Movement](/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement "Non-Aligned Movement") Summit Conference took place in Belgrade, [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia "Yugoslavia") in September 1961

When the war ended, the city was left with 11,500 demolished housing units.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-94)^ During the post-war period, Belgrade grew rapidly as the capital of the [renewed Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia"), developing as a major industrial centre.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-72)^{#cite_ref-beogradrs_72-1}

In 1948, construction of [New Belgrade](/wiki/New_Belgrade "New Belgrade") started. In 1958, Belgrade's first television station began broadcasting. In 1961, Belgrade hosted the first and founding conference of the [Non-Aligned Movement](/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement "Non-Aligned Movement") under Tito's chairmanship.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorris2008134-95)^ In 1962, [Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport](/wiki/Belgrade_Nikola_Tesla_Airport "Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport") was built. In 1968, [major student protests](/wiki/1968_student_demonstrations_in_Belgrade "1968 student demonstrations in Belgrade") led to several street clashes between students and the police.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-96)^{#cite_ref-96}

In 1972, Belgrade faced a [smallpox outbreak](/wiki/1972_Yugoslav_smallpox_outbreak "1972 Yugoslav smallpox outbreak"), the last major outbreak of [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox "Smallpox") in [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe") since World War II.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-97)^ Between October 1977 and March 1978, the city hosted the first major gathering of the [Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe "Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe") with the aim of implementing the [Helsinki Accords](/wiki/Helsinki_Accords "Helsinki Accords") from, while in 1980 Belgrade hosted the [UNESCO General Conference](/wiki/UNESCO_General_Conference "UNESCO General Conference").^[\[95\]](#cite_note-98)^ Josip Broz Tito died in May 1980 and his [funeral](/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Josip_Broz_Tito "Death and state funeral of Josip Broz Tito") in Belgrade was attended by high officials and state delegations from 128 of the 154 [members of the United Nations](/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations "Member states of the United Nations") from all over the world, based on which it became one of the [largest funerals in history](/wiki/List_of_largest_funerals "List of largest funerals").^[\[96\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}  

### Breakup of Yugoslavia {#Breakup_of_Yugoslavia}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Breakup of Yugoslavia")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Beograd_-_Zgrade_General%C5%A1taba_Vojske_Srbije_i_Crne_Gore_i_Ministarstva_odbrane_%2843221947840%29.jpg/220px-Beograd_-_Zgrade_General%C5%A1taba_Vojske_Srbije_i_Crne_Gore_i_Ministarstva_odbrane_%2843221947840%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Beograd_-_Zgrade_General%C5%A1taba_Vojske_Srbije_i_Crne_Gore_i_Ministarstva_odbrane_(43221947840).jpg) Former [Ministry of Defence building](/wiki/Yugoslav_Ministry_of_Defence_building "Yugoslav Ministry of Defence building") damaged in the [1999 NATO bombing](/wiki/NATO_bombing_of_Yugoslavia "NATO bombing of Yugoslavia")

On 9 March 1991, [massive demonstrations](/wiki/March_9,_1991_protest "March 9, 1991 protest") led by [Vuk Drašković](/wiki/Vuk_Dra%C5%A1kovi%C4%87 "Vuk Drašković") were held in the city against [Slobodan Milošević](/wiki/Slobodan_Milo%C5%A1evi%C4%87 "Slobodan Milošević").^[\[97\]](#cite_note-100)^ According to various media outlets, there were between 100,000 and 150,000 people on the streets.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-101)^ Two people were killed, 203 were injured and 108 were arrested during the protests, and later that day tanks were deployed onto the streets to restore order.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-102)^ Many [anti-war protests](/wiki/1991%E2%80%931992_anti-war_protests_in_Belgrade "1991–1992 anti-war protests in Belgrade") were held in Belgrade, with the largest protests being dedicated to solidarity with the victims from the [besieged Sarajevo](/wiki/Siege_of_Sarajevo "Siege of Sarajevo").^[\[100\]](#cite_note-103)^^[\[101\]](#cite_note-104)^ [Further anti-government protests](/wiki/1996%E2%80%931997_protests_in_Serbia "1996–1997 protests in Serbia") were held in Belgrade from November 1996 to February 1997 against the same government after alleged electoral fraud in local elections.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-105)^ These protests brought [Zoran Đinđić](/wiki/Zoran_%C4%90in%C4%91i%C4%87 "Zoran Đinđić") to power, the first [mayor of Belgrade](/wiki/Mayor_of_Belgrade "Mayor of Belgrade") since World War II who did not belong to the [League of Communists of Yugoslavia](/wiki/League_of_Communists_of_Yugoslavia "League of Communists of Yugoslavia") or its later offshoot, the [Socialist Party of Serbia](/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_Serbia "Socialist Party of Serbia").^[\[103\]](#cite_note-106)^{#cite_ref-106}

In 1999, during the [Kosovo War](/wiki/Kosovo_War "Kosovo War"), the [NATO bombing](/wiki/NATO_bombing_of_Yugoslavia "NATO bombing of Yugoslavia") campaign targeted a number a buildings in Belgrade. Among the sites bombed were some ministry buildings, the [RTS](/wiki/Radio_Television_of_Serbia "Radio Television of Serbia") building, hospitals, [Hotel Jugoslavija](/wiki/Hotel_Jugoslavija "Hotel Jugoslavija"), the [Central Committee building](/wiki/U%C5%A1%C4%87e_Tower "Ušće Tower"), [Avala Tower](/wiki/Avala_Tower "Avala Tower"), and the [Chinese embassy](/wiki/NATO_Bombing_of_the_Chinese_embassy_in_Belgrade "NATO Bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade").^[\[104\]](#cite_note-107)^ Between 500^[\[105\]](#cite_note-108)^ and 2,000 civilians^[\[106\]](#cite_note-109)^ were killed in Serbia and Montenegro as a result of the NATO bombings, of which 47 were killed in Belgrade.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-110)^ After the [Yugoslav Wars](/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars "Yugoslav Wars"), Serbia became home to the highest number of [refugees](/wiki/Refugee "Refugee") and [internally displaced persons](/wiki/Internally_displaced_person "Internally displaced person") in Europe, with more than a third of these refugees having settled in Belgrade.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-111)^^[\[109\]](#cite_note-112)^^[\[110\]](#cite_note-113)^^[\[111\]](#cite_note-114)^{#cite_ref-114}

After the [2000 presidential elections](/wiki/2000_Yugoslavian_general_election "2000 Yugoslavian general election"), Belgrade was the site of major public protests, with over half a million people taking part. These demonstrations resulted in the [ousting of president Milošević](/wiki/Overthrow_of_Slobodan_Milo%C5%A1evi%C4%87 "Overthrow of Slobodan Milošević") as a part of the [Otpor](/wiki/Otpor "Otpor") movement.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-115)^^[\[113\]](#cite_note-116)^{#cite_ref-116}  

### Development {#Development}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Development")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Belgrade_Waterfront_12.jpg/900px-Belgrade_Waterfront_12.jpg)](/wiki/File:Belgrade_Waterfront_12.jpg) Belgrade Waterfront (Beograd na Vodi)

In 2014, [Belgrade Waterfront](/wiki/Belgrade_Waterfront "Belgrade Waterfront"), an urban renewal project, was initiated by the [Government of Serbia](/wiki/Government_of_Serbia "Government of Serbia") and its [Emirati](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirati "United Arab Emirati") partner, [Eagle Hills Properties](/wiki/Eagle_Hills_Properties "Eagle Hills Properties"). Around €3.5 billion was to be jointly invested by the Serbian government and their Emirati partners.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-117)^^\[*[needs update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")*\]^ The project includes office and luxury apartment buildings, five-star hotels, a shopping mall and the envisioned '[Belgrade Tower](/wiki/Belgrade_Tower "Belgrade Tower")'. The project is, however, quite controversial---there are a number of uncertainties regarding its funding, necessity, and its architecture's arguable lack of harmony with the rest of the city.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

In addition to [Belgrade Waterfront](/wiki/Belgrade_Waterfront "Belgrade Waterfront"), the city is under rapid development and reconstruction, especially in the area of [Novi Beograd](/wiki/New_Belgrade "New Belgrade"), where (as of 2020) apartment and office buildings were under construction to support the burgeoning [Belgrade IT sector](/wiki/Belgrade_IT_sector "Belgrade IT sector"), now one of Serbia's largest economic players. In September 2020, there were around 2000 active construction sites in Belgrade.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-119)^ The city budget for 2023 stood at 205,5 billion dinars (1.750 billion Euros).^[\[117\]](#cite_note-120)^ The budget for the city of Belgrade has been estimated to be more than 2 billion Euros for 2024.{#cite_ref-120}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Geography")\]  

### Topography {#Topography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Topography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/%D0%A3%D1%88%D1%9B%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B5_%D1%83_%D0%94%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B2_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3_%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B3_%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%B8_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg/220px-%D0%A3%D1%88%D1%9B%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B5_%D1%83_%D0%94%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B2_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3_%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B3_%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%B8_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%A3%D1%88%D1%9B%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B5_%D1%83_%D0%94%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B2_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3_%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B3_%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%B8_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg) The confluence of the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") (river on the right side) into the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") at Belgrade with view on [Kalemegdan Fortress](/wiki/Belgrade_Fortress "Belgrade Fortress") (up-right)

Belgrade lies 116.75 m (383.0 ft) [above sea level](/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level "Above mean sea level") and is located at the [confluence](/wiki/Confluence "Confluence") of the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") and [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") rivers.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-nurden-2009-17)^ The historical core of Belgrade, [Kalemegdan](/wiki/Belgrade_Fortress "Belgrade Fortress"), lies on the right banks of both rivers. Since the 19th century, the city has been expanding to the south and east; after World War II, [New Belgrade](/wiki/New_Belgrade "New Belgrade") was built on the left bank of the Sava river, connecting Belgrade with [Zemun](/wiki/Zemun "Zemun"). Smaller, chiefly residential communities across the Danube, like [Krnjača](/wiki/Krnja%C4%8Da "Krnjača"), [Kotež](/wiki/Kote%C5%BE "Kotež") and [Borča](/wiki/Bor%C4%8Da "Borča"), also merged with the city, while [Pančevo](/wiki/Pan%C4%8Devo "Pančevo"), a heavily industrialised satellite city, remains separate. The city has an urban area of 360 km^2^ (140 sq mi), while together with its metropolitan area it covers 3,223 km^2^ (1,244 sq mi).^[\[11\]](#cite_note-city_of_belgrade-3-13)^{#cite_ref-city_of_belgrade-3_13-3}

On the right bank of the Sava, central Belgrade has a hilly terrain, while the highest point of Belgrade proper is [Torlak hill](/wiki/Torlak_(Belgrade) "Torlak (Belgrade)") at 303 m (994 ft). The mountains of [Avala](/wiki/Avala "Avala") (511 m (1,677 ft)) and [Kosmaj](/wiki/Kosmaj "Kosmaj") (628 m (2,060 ft)) lie south of the city. Across the Sava and Danube, the land is mostly flat, consisting of [alluvial plains](/wiki/Alluvial_plain "Alluvial plain") and [loessial](/wiki/Loam "Loam") [plateaus](/wiki/Plateau "Plateau").^[\[118\]](#cite_note-121)^{#cite_ref-121}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/DJI_0387-12.jpg/220px-DJI_0387-12.jpg)](/wiki/File:DJI_0387-12.jpg) [Monument to the Unknown Hero](/wiki/Monument_to_the_Unknown_Hero "Monument to the Unknown Hero") on the mountain [Avala](/wiki/Avala "Avala"), [Avala Tower](/wiki/Avala_Tower "Avala Tower") and city of Belgrade in distance.

One of the characteristics of the city terrain is [mass wasting](/wiki/Mass_wasting "Mass wasting"). On the territory covered by the General Urban Plan there are 1,155 recorded mass wasting points, out of which 602 are active and 248 are labeled as 'high risk'. They cover almost 30% of the city territory and include several types of mass wasting. [Downhill creeps](/wiki/Downhill_creep "Downhill creep") are located on the slopes above the rivers, mostly on the [clay](/wiki/Clay "Clay") or [loam](/wiki/Loam "Loam") soils, inclined between 7 and 20%. The most critical ones are in [Karaburma](/wiki/Karaburma "Karaburma"), [Zvezdara](/wiki/Zvezdara "Zvezdara"), [Višnjica](/wiki/Vi%C5%A1njica,_Serbia "Višnjica, Serbia"), [Vinča](/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da "Vinča") and [Ritopek](/wiki/Ritopek "Ritopek"), in the Danube valley, and [Umka](/wiki/Umka "Umka"), and especially its neighbourhood of Duboko, in the Sava valley. They have moving and dormant phases, and some of them have been recorded for centuries. Less active downhill creep areas include the entire [Terazije slope](/wiki/Terazijska_Terasa "Terazijska Terasa") above the Sava (Kalemegdan, [Savamala](/wiki/Savamala "Savamala")), which can be seen by the inclination of the [Pobednik](/wiki/Pobednik "Pobednik") monument and the tower of the [Cathedral Church](/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Cathedral,_Belgrade "St. Michael's Cathedral, Belgrade"), and the Voždovac section, between [Banjica](/wiki/Banjica "Banjica") and [Autokomanda](/wiki/Autokomanda "Autokomanda").

Landslides encompass smaller areas, develop on the steep cliffs, sometimes being inclined up to 90%. They are mostly located in the artificial [loess](/wiki/Loess "Loess") hills of Zemun: [Gardoš](/wiki/Gardo%C5%A1 "Gardoš"), [Ćukovac](/wiki/%C4%86ukovac "Ćukovac") and [Kalvarija](/wiki/Kalvarija_(Zemun) "Kalvarija (Zemun)").

However, the majority of the land movement in Belgrade, some 90%, is triggered by the construction works and faulty water supply system (burst pipes, etc.). The neighbourhood of [Mirijevo](/wiki/Mirijevo "Mirijevo") is considered to be the most successful project of fixing the problem. During the construction of the neighbourhood from the 1970s, the terrain was systematically improved and the movement of the land is today completely halted.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-122)^^[\[120\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Under the [Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"), Belgrade has a [humid subtropical climate](/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate") (*Cfa* ) bordering on a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") (*Dfa* ) with four seasons and uniformly spread precipitation. Monthly averages range from 1.9 °C (35.4 °F) in January to 23.8 °C (74.8 °F) in July, with an annual mean of 13.2 °C (55.8 °F). There are, on average, 44.6 days a year when the maximum temperature is at or above 30 °C (86 °F),^[\[121\]](#cite_note-nceinoaagov-124)^ and 95 days when the temperature is above 25 °C (77 °F), On the other hand, Belgrade experiences 52.1 days per year in which the minimum temperature falls below 0 °C (32 °F), with 13.8 days having a maximum temperature below freezing as well.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-nceinoaagov-124)^ Belgrade receives about 698 mm (27 in) of precipitation a year, with late spring being wettest. The average annual number of sunny hours is 2,020.{#cite_ref-nceinoaagov_124-1}

Belgrade may experience thunderstorms at any time of the year, experiencing 31 days annually, but it's much more common in spring and summer months. [Hail](/wiki/Hail "Hail") is rare and occurs exclusively in spring or summer.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-nceinoaagov-124)^{#cite_ref-nceinoaagov_124-2}

The highest officially recorded temperature in Belgrade was 43.6 °C (110.5 °F) on 24 July 2007,^[\[122\]](#cite_note-125)^ while on the other end, the lowest temperature was −26.2 °C (−15 °F) on 10 January 1893.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-126)^ The highest recorded value of daily precipitation was 109.8 millimetres (4.32 inches) on 15 May 2014.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-nceinoaagov-124)^{#cite_ref-nceinoaagov_124-3}

Administration {#Administration}
--------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Administration")\]  
See also: [Mayor of Belgrade](/wiki/Mayor_of_Belgrade "Mayor of Belgrade")

Belgrade is a separate territorial unit in Serbia, with its own autonomous city authority.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-city_of_belgrade-18)^ The Assembly of the City of Belgrade has 110 members, elected on four-year terms.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-130)^ A 13-member City Council, elected by the Assembly and presided over by the mayor and his deputy, has the control and supervision of the city administration,^[\[128\]](#cite_note-131)^ which manages day-to-day administrative affairs. It is divided into 14 Secretariats, each having a specific portfolio such as traffic or health care, and several professional services, agencies and institutes.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}

The [2024 Belgrade City Assembly election](/wiki/2024_Belgrade_City_Assembly_election "2024 Belgrade City Assembly election") was won by the [Serbian Progressive Party](/wiki/Serbian_Progressive_Party "Serbian Progressive Party"), which formed a ruling coalition with the [Socialist Party of Serbia](/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_Serbia "Socialist Party of Serbia"). Between 2004 and 2013, the [Democratic Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Serbia) "Democratic Party (Serbia)") was in power.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-133)^ Due to the importance of Belgrade in political and economic life of Serbia, the office of city's mayor is often described as the third most important office in the state, after the [President of the Government](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Serbia "Prime Minister of Serbia") and the [President of the Republic](/wiki/President_of_Serbia "President of Serbia").^[\[131\]](#cite_note-134)^^[\[132\]](#cite_note-135)^^[\[133\]](#cite_note-136)^{#cite_ref-136}

As the capital city, Belgrade is seat of all Serbian state authorities -- [executive](/wiki/Executive_(government) "Executive (government)"), [legislative](/wiki/Legislative "Legislative"), [judiciary](/wiki/Judiciary "Judiciary"), and the headquarters of almost all national political parties as well as 75 [diplomatic missions](/wiki/Diplomatic_mission "Diplomatic mission").^[\[134\]](#cite_note-137)^ This includes the [National Assembly](/wiki/National_Assembly_(Serbia) "National Assembly (Serbia)"), the Presidency, the [Government of Serbia](/wiki/Government_of_Serbia "Government of Serbia") and all the ministries, [Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_(Serbia) "Supreme Court (Serbia)") and the [Constitutional Court](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Serbia "Constitutional Court of Serbia").{#cite_ref-137}  

### Municipalities {#Municipalities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Municipalities")\]  
See also: [Subdivisions of Belgrade](/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Belgrade "Subdivisions of Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Aerial_view_of_Novi_Beograd_buildings%2C_2024.jpg/220px-Aerial_view_of_Novi_Beograd_buildings%2C_2024.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_Novi_Beograd_buildings,_2024.jpg) Communist brutalist architecture of [New Belgrade](/wiki/New_Belgrade "New Belgrade")

The city is divided into 17 municipalities.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-5-138)^ Previously, they were classified into 10 urban (lying completely or partially within borders of the city proper) and 7 suburban municipalities, whose centres are smaller towns.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-139)^ With the new 2010 City statute, they were all given equal status, with the proviso that suburban ones (except Surčin) have certain autonomous powers, chiefly related with construction, infrastructure and public utilities.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-beogradrs-5-138)^{#cite_ref-beogradrs-5_138-1}

Most of the municipalities are situated on the southern side of the Danube and [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") rivers, in the [Šumadija](/wiki/%C5%A0umadija "Šumadija") region. Three municipalities ([Zemun](/wiki/Zemun "Zemun"), [Novi Beograd](/wiki/New_Belgrade "New Belgrade"), and [Surčin](/wiki/Sur%C4%8Din "Surčin")), are on the northern bank of the Sava in the [Syrmia](/wiki/Syrmia "Syrmia") region and the municipality of [Palilula](/wiki/Palilula_(Belgrade) "Palilula (Belgrade)"), spanning the Danube, is in both the [Šumadija](/wiki/%C5%A0umadija "Šumadija") and [Banat](/wiki/Banat "Banat") regions.

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Demographics")\]  
Main articles: [Demographics of Belgrade](/wiki/Demographics_of_Belgrade "Demographics of Belgrade") and [Demographic history of Belgrade](/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Belgrade "Demographic history of Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Belgrade_oblast_population_pyramid_in_2021.svg/220px-Belgrade_oblast_population_pyramid_in_2021.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Belgrade_oblast_population_pyramid_in_2021.svg) Belgrade oblast population pyramid in 2021

According to the 2022 census, the statistical city proper has a population of 1,197,714, the urban area (with adjacent urban settlements like [Borča](/wiki/Bor%C4%8Da "Borča"), [Ovča](/wiki/Ov%C4%8Da "Ovča"), [Surčin](/wiki/Sur%C4%8Din "Surčin"), etc.) has 1,383,875 inhabitants, while the population of the administrative area of the City of Belgrade (often equated with Belgrade's metropolitan area) stands at 1,681,405 people. However, Belgrade's metropolitan area has not been defined, either statistically or administratively, and it [sprawls](/wiki/Urban_sprawl "Urban sprawl") into the neighboring municipalities like Pančevo, [Opovo](/wiki/Opovo "Opovo"), [Pećinci](/wiki/Pe%C4%87inci "Pećinci") or [Stara Pazova](/wiki/Stara_Pazova "Stara Pazova").

Belgrade is home to many ethnicities from across the former Yugoslavia and the wider Balkans region. The main ethnic group comprising over 86% of the metropolitan population of Belgrade are [Serbs](/wiki/Serbs "Serbs") (1,449,241). Some significant minorities include [Roma](/wiki/Romani_people_in_Serbia "Romani people in Serbia") (23,160), [Yugoslavs](/wiki/Yugoslavs_in_Serbia "Yugoslavs in Serbia") (10,499), [Gorani](/wiki/Gorani_people "Gorani people") (5,249), [Montenegrins](/wiki/Montenegrins_of_Serbia "Montenegrins of Serbia") (5,134), [Russians](/wiki/Russians_in_Serbia "Russians in Serbia") (4,659), [Croats](/wiki/Croats_of_Serbia "Croats of Serbia") (4,554), [Macedonians](/wiki/Macedonians_in_Serbia "Macedonians in Serbia") (4,293), and [ethnic Muslims](/wiki/Muslims_(South-Slavic_ethnic_group) "Muslims (South-Slavic ethnic group)") (2,718).^[\[137\]](#cite_note-140)^ Many people came to the city as economic migrants from smaller towns and the countryside, while tens of thousands arrived as refugees from [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia"), [Bosnia-Herzegovina](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina") and [Kosovo](/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo"), as a result of the [Yugoslav wars](/wiki/Yugoslav_wars "Yugoslav wars") of the 1990s.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-141)^ The most recent wave of immigration following the [Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine") saw tens of thousands of Russians and Ukrainians register their residence in Serbia, majority of them in Belgrade.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-142)^{#cite_ref-142}

Between 10,000 and 20,000^[\[140\]](#cite_note-143)^ [Chinese people](/wiki/Han_Chinese "Han Chinese") are estimated to live in Belgrade and, since their arrival in the mid-1990s, [Block 70](/wiki/Blocks_(New_Belgrade) "Blocks (New Belgrade)") in [New Belgrade](/wiki/New_Belgrade "New Belgrade") has been known colloquially as the Chinese quarter.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-144)^^[\[142\]](#cite_note-145)^ Many [Middle Easterners](/wiki/Middle_Easterners "Middle Easterners"), mainly from [Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria"), [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran"), [Jordan](/wiki/Jordan "Jordan") and [Iraq](/wiki/Iraq "Iraq"), arrived in order to pursue their studies during the 1970s and 1980s, and have remained in the city.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-146)^ Throughout the 19th and early 20th century, small communities of [Aromanians](/wiki/Aromanians "Aromanians"), [Czechs](/wiki/Czechs "Czechs"), [Greeks](/wiki/Greeks "Greeks"), [Germans](/wiki/Germans "Germans"), [Hungarians](/wiki/Hungarians "Hungarians"), [Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews"), [Turks](/wiki/Turkish_people "Turkish people"), [Armenians](/wiki/Armenians "Armenians") and [Russian](/wiki/Russians "Russians") [White émigrés](/wiki/White_%C3%A9migr%C3%A9s "White émigrés") also existed in Belgrade. There are two suburban settlements with significant minority population today: [Ovča](/wiki/Ov%C4%8Da "Ovča") and the village of [Boljevci](/wiki/Boljevci "Boljevci"), both with about one quarter of their population being [Romanians](/wiki/Romanians "Romanians") and [Slovaks](/wiki/Slovaks "Slovaks"), respectively. Immigration to Belgrade from other countries accelerates. In 2023, more than 30,000 foreign workers got working and residence permits only in Belgrade.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-147)^{#cite_ref-147}
