Although there are several historic religious communities in Belgrade, the religious makeup of the city is relatively homogeneous. The [Serbian Orthodox](/wiki/Serbian_Orthodox_Church "Serbian Orthodox Church") community is by far the largest, with 1,475,168 adherents. There are also 31,914 Muslims, 13,720 Roman Catholics, and 3,128 [Protestants](/wiki/Protestantism "Protestantism").

There once was a significant [Jewish community](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Serbia "History of the Jews in Serbia") in Belgrade but, following the World War II [Nazi occupation](/wiki/History_of_Serbia#Serbia_in_World_War_I "History of Serbia") of the city and subsequent Jewish emigration, their numbers have fallen from over 10,000 to just 295.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-152)^ Belgrade also used to have one of the largest [Buddhist](/wiki/Buddhist "Buddhist") colonies in Europe outside Russia when some 400 mostly Buddhist [Kalmyks](/wiki/Kalmyks "Kalmyks") settled on the outskirts of Belgrade following the [Russian Civil War](/wiki/Russian_Civil_War "Russian Civil War"). The first Buddhist temple in Europe was built in Belgrade in 1929. Most of them moved away after the World War II and their temple, [Belgrade pagoda](/wiki/Belgrade_pagoda "Belgrade pagoda"), was abandoned, claimed by the new Communist regime and eventually demolished.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-153)^{#cite_ref-153}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Belgrade](/wiki/Economy_of_Belgrade "Economy of Belgrade")  
See also: [Belgrade IT sector](/wiki/Belgrade_IT_sector "Belgrade IT sector") and [Architectural projects in Belgrade](/wiki/Architectural_projects_in_Belgrade "Architectural projects in Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Zgrada_Ministarstva_saobra%C4%87aja_u_Beogradu_2006.jpg/220px-Zgrada_Ministarstva_saobra%C4%87aja_u_Beogradu_2006.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zgrada_Ministarstva_saobra%C4%87aja_u_Beogradu_2006.jpg) [Serbian Railways](/wiki/Serbian_Railways "Serbian Railways") headquarters in Belgrade [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%B8_%282017%29.jpg/220px-%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%B8_%282017%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%B8_(2017).jpg) Headquarters of [Serbian National Bank](/wiki/National_Bank_of_Serbia "National Bank of Serbia")

Belgrade is the [financial centre](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre") of Serbia and [Southeast Europe](/wiki/Southeast_Europe "Southeast Europe"), with a total of 17×10\^^6^ m^2^ (180×10\^^6^ sq ft) of office space.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-154)^ It is also home to the country's [Central Bank](/wiki/National_Bank_of_Serbia "National Bank of Serbia"). 750,550 people are employed (July 2020)^[\[152\]](#cite_note-biznistelegrafrs-2020-155)^ in 120,286 companies,^[\[153\]](#cite_note-večernje_novosti-2013-156)^ 76,307 enterprises and 50,000 shops.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-biznistelegrafrs-2020-155)^^[\[154\]](#cite_note-157)^ The City of Belgrade itself owns 267,147 m^2^ (2,875,550 sq ft) of rentable office space.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}

As of 2019, Belgrade contained 31.4% of Serbia's employed population and generated over 40.4% of its GDP.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-159)^^[\[157\]](#cite_note-160)^^[\[158\]](#cite_note-161)^ City GDP in 2023 at purchasing power parity is estimated at $73 bn USD, which is $43,400 per capita in terms of purchasing power parity. Nominal GDP in 2023 is estimated at $31.5 bn USD, which is $18.700 per capita.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-162)^{#cite_ref-162}

[New Belgrade](/wiki/New_Belgrade "New Belgrade") is the country's [Central business district](/wiki/Central_business_district "Central business district") and one of [Southeastern Europe](/wiki/Southeastern_Europe "Southeastern Europe")'s financial centres. It offers a range of facilities, such as hotels, congress halls (e.g. [Sava Centar](/wiki/Sava_Centar "Sava Centar")), Class A and B office buildings, and business parks (e.g. [Airport City Belgrade](/wiki/Airport_City_Belgrade "Airport City Belgrade")). Over 1.2×10\^^6^ m^2^ (13×10\^^6^ sq ft) of land is under construction in New Belgrade, with the value of planned construction over the next three years estimated at over 1.5 billion euros. The [Belgrade Stock Exchange](/wiki/Belgrade_Stock_Exchange "Belgrade Stock Exchange") is also located in New Belgrade.

With 6,924 companies in the IT sector (according to 2013 data^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit)^), Belgrade is one of the foremost [information technology](/wiki/Information_technology "Information technology") hubs in [Southeast Europe](/wiki/Southeast_Europe "Southeast Europe").^[\[153\]](#cite_note-večernje_novosti-2013-156)^ [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft")'s [Development Center Serbia](/wiki/Microsoft_Development_Center_Serbia "Microsoft Development Center Serbia"), located in Belgrade, was, at the time of its establishment, the fifth such programme on the globe.^[\[160\]](#cite_note-163)^ Many global IT companies choose Belgrade as their European or regional centre of operations, such as [Asus](/wiki/Asus "Asus"),^[\[161\]](#cite_note-164)^ [Intel](/wiki/Intel "Intel"),^[\[162\]](#cite_note-165)^ [Dell](/wiki/Dell "Dell"),^[\[163\]](#cite_note-166)^ [Huawei](/wiki/Huawei "Huawei"), [Nutanix](/wiki/Nutanix "Nutanix"),^[\[164\]](#cite_note-167)^ [NCR](/wiki/NCR_Corporation "NCR Corporation") etc.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-168)^ The most famous Belgrade IT startups, among others, are [Nordeus](/wiki/Nordeus "Nordeus"), [ComTrade Group](/wiki/ComTrade_Group "ComTrade Group"), [MicroE](/wiki/Mikroelektronika "Mikroelektronika"), [FishingBooker](/wiki/FishingBooker "FishingBooker"), and [Endava](/wiki/Endava_d.o.o. "Endava d.o.o."). IT facilities in the city include the [Mihajlo Pupin Institute](/wiki/Mihajlo_Pupin_Institute "Mihajlo Pupin Institute") and the [ILR](/wiki/Ivo_Lola_Ribar_Institute "Ivo Lola Ribar Institute"),^[\[166\]](#cite_note-169)^ as well as the brand-new IT Park Zvezdara.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-170)^ Many prominent IT innovators began their careers in Belgrade, including [Voja Antonić](/wiki/Voja_Antoni%C4%87 "Voja Antonić") and [Veselin Jevrosimović](/wiki/Veselin_Jevrosimovi%C4%87 "Veselin Jevrosimović").{#cite_ref-170}

In December 2021, the average Belgrade monthly net salary stood at 94,463 RSD ($946) in net terms, with the gross equivalent at 128,509 RSD ($1288), while in New Belgrade CBD is Euros 1,059.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-171)^ 88% of the city's households owned a computer, 89% had a broadband internet connection and 93% had [pay television](/wiki/Pay_television "Pay television") services.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-172)^{#cite_ref-172}

According to [Cushman \& Wakefield](/wiki/Cushman_%26_Wakefield "Cushman & Wakefield"), [Knez Mihajlova](/wiki/Knez_Mihajlova "Knez Mihajlova") street is 36th most expensive retail street in the world in terms of renting commercial space.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-173)^{#cite_ref-173}

As an example of the attractiveness of the city and its importance in this part of the continent is the fact that numerous multinational companies choose precisely Belgrade to place its local headquarters. An early example of this was the multinational food-giant [McDonald's](/wiki/McDonald%27s "McDonald's") opening its first ever restaurant in a communist country in Europe in Belgrade.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-174)^{#cite_ref-174}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Culture")\]  
Main article: [Culture of Belgrade](/wiki/Culture_of_Belgrade "Culture of Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Republic_Square_%2827420599076%29.jpg/220px-Republic_Square_%2827420599076%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Republic_Square_(27420599076).jpg) [Republic Square](/wiki/Republic_Square_(Belgrade) "Republic Square (Belgrade)"), Left: [National Museum of Serbia](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Serbia "National Museum of Serbia") -- Centre: [Courtyard by Marriott](/wiki/Courtyard_by_Marriott "Courtyard by Marriott") Hotel Belgrade -- Right: [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Belgrade "National Theatre in Belgrade"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Serbian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts%2C_Knez_Mihailova_%2813810271995%29.jpg/220px-Serbian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts%2C_Knez_Mihailova_%2813810271995%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Serbian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts,_Knez_Mihailova_(13810271995).jpg) The [Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts](/wiki/Serbian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts "Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts"), national learned society founded in 1841

According to the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC"), Belgrade is one of the five most creative cities in the world.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-175)^ Belgrade hosts many annual international cultural events, including the [Film Festival](/wiki/FEST_(Belgrade) "FEST (Belgrade)"), [Theatre Festival](/wiki/Belgrade_International_Theatre_Festival "Belgrade International Theatre Festival"), [Summer Festival](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade_Summer_Festival&action=edit&redlink=1 "Belgrade Summer Festival (page does not exist)"), [BEMUS](/wiki/Belgrade_Music_Festival "Belgrade Music Festival"), [Belgrade Early Music Festival](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade_Early_Music_Festival&action=edit&redlink=1 "Belgrade Early Music Festival (page does not exist)"), [Book Fair](/wiki/Belgrade_Book_Fair "Belgrade Book Fair"), [Belgrade Choir Festival](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade_Choir_Festival&action=edit&redlink=1 "Belgrade Choir Festival (page does not exist)"), [Eurovision Song Contest 2008](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2008 "Eurovision Song Contest 2008"), and the [Beer Fest](/wiki/Belgrade_Beer_Fest "Belgrade Beer Fest").^[\[173\]](#cite_note-176)^ In 2022 Belgrade was also home to the [Europride](/wiki/EuroPride "EuroPride") event, even though the Serbian president, Aleksandar Vučić, tried to cancel it.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-177)^ The [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature") winning author [Ivo Andrić](/wiki/Ivo_Andri%C4%87 "Ivo Andrić") wrote his most famous work, *[The Bridge on the Drina](/wiki/The_Bridge_on_the_Drina "The Bridge on the Drina")* , in Belgrade.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-178)^ Other prominent Belgrade authors include [Branislav Nušić](/wiki/Branislav_Nu%C5%A1i%C4%87 "Branislav Nušić"), [Miloš Crnjanski](/wiki/Milo%C5%A1_Crnjanski "Miloš Crnjanski"), [Borislav Pekić](/wiki/Borislav_Peki%C4%87 "Borislav Pekić"), [Milorad Pavić](/wiki/Milorad_Pavi%C4%87_(writer) "Milorad Pavić (writer)") and [Meša Selimović](/wiki/Me%C5%A1a_Selimovi%C4%87 "Meša Selimović").^[\[176\]](#cite_note-179)^^[\[177\]](#cite_note-180)^^[\[178\]](#cite_note-181)^ The most internationally prominent artists from Belgrade are [Charles Simic](/wiki/Charles_Simic "Charles Simic"), [Marina Abramović](/wiki/Marina_Abramovi%C4%87 "Marina Abramović") and [Milovan Destil Marković](/wiki/Milovan_Destil_Markovi%C4%87 "Milovan Destil Marković").{#cite_ref-181}

Most of [Serbia's film industry](/wiki/Cinema_of_Serbia "Cinema of Serbia") is based in Belgrade. [FEST](/wiki/FEST_(Belgrade) "FEST (Belgrade)") is an annual film festival that has been held since 1971. Through 2013, the festival had been attended by four million people and had presented almost 4,000 films.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-182)^{#cite_ref-182}

The city was one of the main centres of the [Yugoslav new wave](/wiki/New_wave_music_in_Yugoslavia "New wave music in Yugoslavia") in the 1980s: [VIS Idoli](/wiki/VIS_Idoli "VIS Idoli"), [Ekatarina Velika](/wiki/Ekatarina_Velika "Ekatarina Velika"), [Šarlo Akrobata](/wiki/%C5%A0arlo_Akrobata "Šarlo Akrobata") and [Električni Orgazam](/wiki/Elektri%C4%8Dni_Orgazam "Električni Orgazam") were all from Belgrade. Other notable Belgrade rock acts include [Riblja Čorba](/wiki/Riblja_%C4%8Corba "Riblja Čorba"), [Bajaga i Instruktori](/wiki/Bajaga_i_Instruktori "Bajaga i Instruktori") and [Partibrejkers](/wiki/Partibrejkers "Partibrejkers").^[\[180\]](#cite_note-183)^^[\[181\]](#cite_note-184)^ Today, it is the centre of the [Serbian hip hop](/wiki/Serbian_hip_hop "Serbian hip hop") scene, with acts such as [Beogradski Sindikat](/wiki/Beogradski_Sindikat "Beogradski Sindikat"), [Bad Copy](/wiki/Bad_Copy "Bad Copy"), [Škabo](/wiki/%C5%A0kabo "Škabo"), [Marčelo](/wiki/Mar%C4%8Delo "Marčelo"), and most of the Bassivity Music stable hailing from or living in the city.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-185)^^[\[183\]](#cite_note-186)^ There are numerous theatres, the most prominent of which are [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Belgrade "National Theatre in Belgrade"), [Theatre on Terazije](/wiki/Theatre_on_Terazije "Theatre on Terazije"), [Yugoslav Drama Theatre](/wiki/Yugoslav_Drama_Theatre "Yugoslav Drama Theatre"), [Zvezdara Theatre](/w/index.php?title=Zvezdara_Theatre&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zvezdara Theatre (page does not exist)"), and [Atelier 212](/wiki/Atelje_212 "Atelje 212"). The [Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts](/wiki/Serbian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts "Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts") is also based in Belgrade, as well as the [National Library of Serbia](/wiki/National_Library_of_Serbia "National Library of Serbia"). Other major libraries include the Belgrade City Library and the [Belgrade University Library](/wiki/Belgrade_University_Library "Belgrade University Library"). Belgrade's two opera houses are: [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Belgrade "National Theatre in Belgrade") and [Madlenianum Opera House](/wiki/Madlenianum_Opera_and_Theatre "Madlenianum Opera and Theatre").^[\[184\]](#cite_note-187)^^[\[185\]](#cite_note-188)^ Following the victory of Serbia's representative [Marija Šerifović](/wiki/Marija_%C5%A0erifovi%C4%87 "Marija Šerifović") at the [Eurovision Song Contest 2007](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2007 "Eurovision Song Contest 2007"), Belgrade hosted the Contest in [2008](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2008 "Eurovision Song Contest 2008").^[\[186\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}

There are more than 1650 [public sculptures](/wiki/Public_sculpture "Public sculpture") in Belgrade.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-190)^^[\[188\]](#cite_note-191)^{#cite_ref-191}  

### Museums {#Museums}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Museums")\]  
See also: [List of museums in Belgrade](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Belgrade "List of museums in Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Museum_of_Yugoslavia.jpg/220px-Museum_of_Yugoslavia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Museum_of_Yugoslavia.jpg) [Museum of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Museum_of_Yugoslavia "Museum of Yugoslavia")

The most prominent museum in Belgrade is the [National Museum](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Serbia "National Museum of Serbia"), founded in 1844 and reconstructed from 2003 until June 2018. The museum houses a collection of more than 400,000 exhibits (over 5600 paintings and 8400 drawings and prints, including many foreign masters like [Bosch](/wiki/Hieronymus_Bosch "Hieronymus Bosch"), [Juan de Flandes](/wiki/Juan_de_Flandes "Juan de Flandes"), [Titian](/wiki/Titian "Titian"), [Tintoretto](/wiki/Tintoretto "Tintoretto"), [Rubens](/wiki/Peter_Paul_Rubens "Peter Paul Rubens"), [Cézanne](/wiki/C%C3%A9zanne "Cézanne"), [G.B. Tiepolo](/wiki/Giovanni_Battista_Tiepolo "Giovanni Battista Tiepolo"), [Renoir](/wiki/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir "Pierre-Auguste Renoir"), [Monet](/wiki/Claude_Monet "Claude Monet"), [Lautrec](/wiki/Henri_de_Toulouse-Lautrec "Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec"), [Matisse](/wiki/Henri_Matisse "Henri Matisse"), [Picasso](/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso"), [Gauguin](/wiki/Paul_Gauguin "Paul Gauguin"), [Chagall](/wiki/Marc_Chagall "Marc Chagall"), [Van Gogh](/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh "Vincent van Gogh"), [Mondrian](/wiki/Piet_Mondrian "Piet Mondrian") etc.) and also the famous [Miroslav's Gospel](/wiki/Miroslav%27s_Gospel "Miroslav's Gospel").^[\[189\]](#cite_note-192)^ The [Ethnographic Museum](/wiki/Ethnographic_Museum_(Belgrade) "Ethnographic Museum (Belgrade)"), established in 1901, contains more than 150,000 items showcasing the rural and urban culture of the Balkans, particularly the countries of [former Yugoslavia](/wiki/Former_Yugoslavia "Former Yugoslavia").^[\[190\]](#cite_note-193)^{#cite_ref-193}

The [Museum of Contemporary Art](/wiki/Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_(Belgrade) "Museum of Contemporary Art (Belgrade)") was the first contemporary art museum in Yugoslavia and one of the first museums of this type in the world.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-194)^ Following its foundation in 1965, has amassed a collection of more than 8,000 works from art produced across the former Yugoslavia.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-195)^ The collection represents some of the most notable Serbian and Yugoslav 20th century artists, including [Sava Šumanović](/wiki/Sava_%C5%A0umanovi%C4%87 "Sava Šumanović"), [Nadežda Petrović](/wiki/Nade%C5%BEda_Petrovi%C4%87 "Nadežda Petrović"), [Petar Dobrović](/wiki/Petar_Dobrovi%C4%87 "Petar Dobrović"), [Milena Pavlović-Barili](/wiki/Milena_Pavlovi%C4%87-Barili "Milena Pavlović-Barili"), [Milan Konjović](/wiki/Milan_Konjovi%C4%87 "Milan Konjović"), [Zora Petrović](/wiki/Zora_Petrovi%C4%87 "Zora Petrović"), [Đorđe Andrejević Kun](/wiki/%C4%90or%C4%91e_Andrejevi%C4%87_Kun "Đorđe Andrejević Kun"), [Vladimir Veličković](/wiki/Vladimir_Veli%C4%8Dkovi%C4%87 "Vladimir Veličković"), [Petar Lubarda](/wiki/Petar_Lubarda "Petar Lubarda"), [Krsto Hegedušić](/wiki/Krsto_Hegedu%C5%A1i%C4%87 "Krsto Hegedušić"), [Mića Popović](/wiki/Mi%C4%87a_Popovi%C4%87 "Mića Popović"), [Ivan Meštrović](/wiki/Ivan_Me%C5%A1trovi%C4%87 "Ivan Meštrović"), [Antun Augustinčić](/wiki/Antun_Augustin%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Antun Augustinčić"), [Toma Rosandić](/wiki/Toma_Rosandi%C4%87 "Toma Rosandić"), [Olga Jevrić](/wiki/Olga_Jevri%C4%87 "Olga Jevrić"), [Olga Jančić](/wiki/Olga_Jan%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Olga Jančić"), [Lojze Dolinar](/wiki/Lojze_Dolinar "Lojze Dolinar"), among others.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-196)^^[\[194\]](#cite_note-197)^ The museum was closed in 2007, but has since been reopened in 2017 to focus on the modern as well as on the Yugoslav art scenes.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-198)^ Artist [Marina Abramović](/wiki/Marina_Abramovi%C4%87 "Marina Abramović"), who was born in Belgrade, held an exhibition in the Museum of Contemporary Art, which the *[New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")* described as one of the most important cultural happenings in the world in 2019.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-199)^^[\[197\]](#cite_note-200)^ The exhibition was seen by almost 100,000 visitors. Marina Abramović made a stage speech and performance in front of 20,000 people.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-201)^ In the heart of Belgrade you can also find the [Museum of Applied Arts](/wiki/Museum_of_Applied_Arts,_Belgrade "Museum of Applied Arts, Belgrade"), a museum that has been awarded for the Institution of the Year 2016 by [ICOM](/wiki/International_Council_of_Museums "International Council of Museums").^[\[199\]](#cite_note-202)^{#cite_ref-202}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Museum_of_contemporary_art%2C_Belgrade_%28%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D1%98_%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%29.jpg/220px-Museum_of_contemporary_art%2C_Belgrade_%28%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D1%98_%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Museum_of_contemporary_art,_Belgrade_(%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D1%98_%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4).jpg) [Museum of Contemporary Art](/wiki/Museum_of_Contemporary_Art,_Belgrade "Museum of Contemporary Art, Belgrade")

The [Military Museum](/wiki/Military_Museum_(Belgrade) "Military Museum (Belgrade)"), established in 1878 in Kalemegdan, houses a wide range of more than 25,000 military objects dating from the prehistoric to the medieval to the modern eras. Notable items include Turkish and oriental arms, national banners, and [Yugoslav Partisan](/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans "Yugoslav Partisans") regalia.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-203)^^[\[201\]](#cite_note-204)^{#cite_ref-204}

The [Museum of Aviation in Belgrade](/wiki/Museum_of_Aviation_in_Belgrade "Museum of Aviation in Belgrade") located near [Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport](/wiki/Belgrade_Nikola_Tesla_Airport "Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport") has more than 200 aircraft, of which about 50 are on display, and a few of which are the only surviving examples of their type, such as the [Fiat G.50](/wiki/Fiat_G.50 "Fiat G.50"). This museum also displays parts of shot down US and [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO") aircraft, such as the [F-117](/wiki/F-117_Nighthawk "F-117 Nighthawk") and [F-16](/wiki/F-16_Fighting_Falcon "F-16 Fighting Falcon").^[\[202\]](#cite_note-205)^{#cite_ref-205}

The [Nikola Tesla Museum](/wiki/Nikola_Tesla_Museum "Nikola Tesla Museum"), founded in 1952, preserves the personal items of [Nikola Tesla](/wiki/Nikola_Tesla "Nikola Tesla"), the inventor after whom the [Tesla unit](/wiki/Tesla_(unit) "Tesla (unit)") was named. It holds around 160,000 original documents and around 5,700 personal other items including his urn.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-206)^ The last of the major Belgrade museums is the [Museum of Vuk and Dositej](/wiki/Museum_of_Vuk_and_Dositej "Museum of Vuk and Dositej"), which showcases the lives, work and legacy of [Vuk Stefanović Karadžić](/wiki/Vuk_Stefanovi%C4%87_Karad%C5%BEi%C4%87 "Vuk Stefanović Karadžić") and [Dositej Obradović](/wiki/Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87 "Dositej Obradović"), the 19th century reformer of the Serbian literary language and the first Serbian Minister of Education, respectively.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-207)^ Belgrade also houses the [Museum of African Art](/wiki/Museum_of_African_Art,_Serbia "Museum of African Art, Serbia"), founded in 1977, which has a large collection of art from West Africa.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-208)^{#cite_ref-208}

With around 95,000 copies of national and international films, the [Yugoslav Film Archive](/wiki/Yugoslav_Film_Archive "Yugoslav Film Archive") is the largest in the region and among the 10 largest archives in the world.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-209)^ The institution also operates the Museum of Yugoslav Film Archive, with movie theatre and exhibition hall. The archive's long-standing storage problems were finally solved in 2007, when a new modern depository was opened.^[\[207\]](#cite_note-210)^ The [Yugoslav Film Archive](/wiki/Yugoslav_Film_Archive "Yugoslav Film Archive") also exhibits original [Charlie Chaplin](/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin "Charlie Chaplin")'s stick and one of the first movies by [Auguste and Louis Lumière](/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re "Auguste and Louis Lumière").^[\[208\]](#cite_note-211)^{#cite_ref-211}

The [Belgrade City Museum](/wiki/Belgrade_City_Museum "Belgrade City Museum") moved into a new building in downtown in 2006.^[\[209\]](#cite_note-212)^ The museum hosts a range of collections covering the history of urban life since prehistory.^[\[210\]](#cite_note-213)^ Belgrade City Museum also includes additional sites, such as [Ivo Andrić Museum](/wiki/Museum_of_Ivo_Andri%C4%87 "Museum of Ivo Andrić"), [Princess Ljubica's Residence](/wiki/Princess_Ljubica%27s_Residence "Princess Ljubica's Residence"), [Paja Jovanović Museum](/wiki/Museum_of_Paja_Jovanovi%C4%87 "Museum of Paja Jovanović"), [Jovan Cvijić Museum](/wiki/Jovan_Cviji%C4%87_House "Jovan Cvijić House").^[\[211\]](#cite_note-214)^ The [Museum of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Museum_of_Yugoslavia "Museum of Yugoslavia") has collections from the Yugoslav era. Beside paintings, the most valuable are [Moon](/wiki/Moon "Moon") rocks donated by [Apollo 11](/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") crew [Neil Armstrong](/wiki/Neil_Armstrong "Neil Armstrong"), [Buzz Aldrin](/wiki/Buzz_Aldrin "Buzz Aldrin") and [Michael Collins](/wiki/Michael_Collins_(astronaut) "Michael Collins (astronaut)") while visiting Belgrade in 1969 and from mission [Apollo 17](/wiki/Apollo_17 "Apollo 17") donated by [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") in 1971.^[\[212\]](#cite_note-215)^ The museum also houses [Joseph Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin")'s sabre with 260 brilliants and diamonds, donated by Stalin himself.^[\[213\]](#cite_note-216)^ The [Museum of Science and Technology](/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Science_and_Technology_(Belgrade)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Museum of Science and Technology (Belgrade) (page does not exist)"), founded in 1989, moved to the building of the first city's power plant in Dorćol in 2005.^[\[214\]](#cite_note-217)^^[\[215\]](#cite_note-218)^{#cite_ref-218}  

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Architecture")\]  
See also: [List of buildings in Belgrade](/wiki/List_of_buildings_in_Belgrade "List of buildings in Belgrade"), [List of streets and squares in Belgrade](/wiki/List_of_streets_and_squares_in_Belgrade "List of streets and squares in Belgrade"), [Bridges of Belgrade](/wiki/Bridges_of_Belgrade "Bridges of Belgrade"), [Architectural projects in Belgrade](/wiki/Architectural_projects_in_Belgrade "Architectural projects in Belgrade"), [Religious architecture in Belgrade](/wiki/Religious_architecture_in_Belgrade "Religious architecture in Belgrade"), and [Gates of Belgrade](/wiki/Gates_of_Belgrade "Gates of Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Palata_Albanija_01.jpg/220px-Palata_Albanija_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Palata_Albanija_01.jpg) [Palace Albanija](/wiki/Palace_Albanija "Palace Albanija")

Belgrade has wildly varying architecture, from the centre of [Zemun](/wiki/Zemun "Zemun"), typical of a Central European town,^[\[216\]](#cite_note-219)^ to the more modern architecture and spacious layout of [New Belgrade](/wiki/Novi_Beograd "Novi Beograd").{#cite_ref-219}

The oldest architecture is found in Kalemegdan Park. Outside of Kalemegdan, the oldest buildings date only from the 18th century, due to its geographic position and frequent wars and destructions.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-manević-220)^ The oldest public structure in Belgrade is a nondescript Turkish [türbe](/wiki/T%C3%BCrbe "Türbe"), while the oldest house is a modest clay house on [Dorćol](/wiki/Dor%C4%87ol "Dorćol"), from late 18th century.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-221)^ Western influence began in the 19th century, when the city completely transformed from an oriental town to the contemporary architecture of the time, with influences from [neoclassicism](/wiki/Neoclassicism "Neoclassicism"), [romanticism](/wiki/Romanticism "Romanticism"), and [academic art](/wiki/Academic_art "Academic art"). Serbian architects took over the development from foreign builders in the late 19th century, producing the [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Belgrade "National Theatre in Belgrade"), [Stari Dvor](/wiki/Stari_dvor "Stari dvor"), [Cathedral Church](/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Cathedral_(Belgrade) "St. Michael's Cathedral (Belgrade)") and later, in the early 20th century, the [House of the National Assembly](/wiki/House_of_the_National_Assembly,_Belgrade "House of the National Assembly, Belgrade") and [National Museum](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Serbia "National Museum of Serbia"), influenced by [art nouveau](/wiki/Art_nouveau "Art nouveau").^[\[217\]](#cite_note-manević-220)^ Elements of [Serbo-Byzantine Revival](/wiki/Serbo-Byzantine_Revival "Serbo-Byzantine Revival") are present in buildings such as [Vuk Foundation House](/wiki/Vuk_Foundation_House "Vuk Foundation House"), old Post Office in Kosovska street, and sacral architecture, such as [St. Mark's Church](/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Church,_Belgrade "St. Mark's Church, Belgrade") (based on the [Gračanica monastery](/wiki/Gra%C4%8Danica_monastery "Gračanica monastery")), and the [Church of Saint Sava](/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Sava "Church of Saint Sava").^[\[217\]](#cite_note-manević-220)^ In the socialist period, housing was built quickly and cheaply for the huge influx of people fleeing the countryside following World War II, sometimes resulting in the [brutalist architecture](/wiki/Brutalist_architecture "Brutalist architecture") of the [*blokovi*](/wiki/Blocks_(New_Belgrade) "Blocks (New Belgrade)") ('blocks') of [New Belgrade](/wiki/New_Belgrade "New Belgrade"); a [socrealism](/wiki/Socrealism "Socrealism") trend briefly ruled, resulting in buildings like the [Trade Union Hall](/wiki/Dom_Sindikata "Dom Sindikata").^[\[217\]](#cite_note-manević-220)^ However, in the mid-1950s, [modernist](/wiki/Modernism "Modernism") trends took over, and still dominate the Belgrade architecture.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-manević-220)^ Belgrade has the second oldest sewer system in Europe.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-222)^ The [Clinical Centre of Serbia](/wiki/Clinical_Centre_of_Serbia "Clinical Centre of Serbia") spreads over 34 hectares and consists of about 50 buildings, while also has 3,150 beds considered to be the highest number in Europe,^[\[220\]](#cite_note-223)^ and among [highest in the world](/wiki/List_of_hospitals_by_capacity "List of hospitals by capacity").^[\[221\]](#cite_note-224)^{#cite_ref-224}  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Tourism")\]  
See also: [Tourism in Serbia](/wiki/Tourism_in_Serbia "Tourism in Serbia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/%D0%A6%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D1%81%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B3_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B5%2C_%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%28Church_of_Saint_Sava%2C_2023%29.jpg/220px-%D0%A6%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D1%81%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B3_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B5%2C_%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%28Church_of_Saint_Sava%2C_2023%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%A6%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D1%81%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B3_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B5,_%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_(Church_of_Saint_Sava,_2023).jpg) [Church of Saint Sava](/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Sava "Church of Saint Sava")

Lying on the main artery connecting Europe and Asia, as well as, eventually, the [Orient Express](/wiki/Orient_Express "Orient Express"), Belgrade has been a popular place for travellers through the centuries. In 1843, on Dubrovačka Street (today Kralj Petar Street ), Serbia's *[knez](/wiki/Knez_(title) "Knez (title)")* [Mihailo Obrenović](/wiki/Mihailo_Obrenovi%C4%87 "Mihailo Obrenović") built a large edifice which became the first hotel in Belgrade: *Kod jelena* ('at the deer's'), in the neighbourhood of [Kosančićev Venac](/wiki/Kosan%C4%8Di%C4%87ev_Venac "Kosančićev Venac"). Many criticised the move at the time due to the cost and the size of the building, but it soon became the gathering point of the Principality's wealthiest citizens. Colloquially, the building was also referred to as the *staro zdanje* , or the 'old edifice'. It remained a hotel until 1903 before being demolished in 1938.^[\[222\]](#cite_note-225)^^[\[223\]](#cite_note-226)^ After the *staro zdanje* , numerous hotels were built in the second half of the 19th century: *Nacional* and *Grand* , also in Kosančićev Venac, *Srpski Kralj* , *Srpska Kruna* , *[Grčka Kraljica](/wiki/Gr%C4%8Dka_Kraljica "Grčka Kraljica")* near Kalemegdan, *Balkan* and *Pariz* in [Terazije](/wiki/Terazije "Terazije"), *[London](/wiki/London,_Belgrade "London, Belgrade")* , etc.^[\[224\]](#cite_note-perić-2018-227)^{#cite_ref-perić-2018_227-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/DJI_0136-12.jpg/220px-DJI_0136-12.jpg)](/wiki/File:DJI_0136-12.jpg) [Kalemegdan](/wiki/Kalemegdan "Kalemegdan") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Botani%C4%8Dka_ba%C5%A1ta_Jevremovac%2C_Beograd_-_Japanski_vrt_07.jpg/220px-Botani%C4%8Dka_ba%C5%A1ta_Jevremovac%2C_Beograd_-_Japanski_vrt_07.jpg)](/wiki/File:Botani%C4%8Dka_ba%C5%A1ta_Jevremovac,_Beograd_-_Japanski_vrt_07.jpg) [Jevremovac Botanical Garden](/wiki/Jevremovac "Jevremovac")

As Belgrade became connected via steamboats and railway (after 1884), the number of visitors grew and new hotels were opened with luxurious commodities. In Savamala, the hotels *Bosna* and *Bristol* were opened. Other hotels included *Solun* and *Orient* , which was built near the [Financial Park](/wiki/Financial_Park "Financial Park"). Tourists who arrived by the [Orient Express](/wiki/Orient_Express "Orient Express") mostly stayed at the Petrograd Hotel in [Wilson Square](/wiki/Savamala#Sava_Square "Savamala"). Hotel *Srpski Kralj* , at the corner of Uzun Mirkova and Pariska Streets was considered the best hotel in Belgrade during the [Interbellum](/wiki/Interbellum "Interbellum"). It was destroyed during World War II.^[\[224\]](#cite_note-perić-2018-227)^{#cite_ref-perić-2018_227-1}

The historic areas and buildings of Belgrade are among the city's premier attractions. They include [Skadarlija](/wiki/Skadarlija "Skadarlija"), the [National Museum](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Serbia "National Museum of Serbia") and adjacent [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Belgrade "National Theatre in Belgrade"), [Zemun](/wiki/Zemun "Zemun"), [Nikola Pašić Square](/wiki/Nikola_Pa%C5%A1i%C4%87_Square "Nikola Pašić Square"), Terazije, [Students' Square](/wiki/Studentski_Trg "Studentski Trg"), the [Kalemegdan Fortress](/wiki/Belgrade_Fortress "Belgrade Fortress"), [Knez Mihailova Street](/wiki/Knez_Mihailova "Knez Mihailova"), the [Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Serbia "Parliament of Serbia"), the [Church of Saint Sava](/wiki/Temple_of_Saint_Sava "Temple of Saint Sava"), and the [Old Palace](/wiki/The_Old_Palace "The Old Palace"). On top of this, there are many parks, monuments, museums, cafés, restaurants and shops on both sides of the river. The hilltop [Avala Monument](/wiki/Monument_to_the_Unknown_Hero "Monument to the Unknown Hero") and [Avala Tower](/wiki/Avala_Tower "Avala Tower") offer views over the city. According to *The Guardian* , [Dorćol](/wiki/Dor%C4%87ol "Dorćol") is the one of top ten coolest suburbs in Europe.^[\[225\]](#cite_note-228)^ The elite neighbourhood of [Dedinje](/wiki/Dedinje "Dedinje") is situated near the [Topčider](/wiki/Top%C4%8Dider "Topčider") and [Košutnjak](/wiki/Ko%C5%A1utnjak "Košutnjak") parks. The [Dedinje Royal Compound](/wiki/Dedinje_Royal_Compound "Dedinje Royal Compound") which houses the former royal residences of ([Kraljevski Dvor](/wiki/Kraljevski_Dvor "Kraljevski Dvor") and [Beli Dvor](/wiki/Beli_dvor "Beli dvor")) is open for visitors. The palace has many valuable artworks.^[\[226\]](#cite_note-229)^ Nearby, [Josip Broz Tito](/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito "Josip Broz Tito")'s mausoleum, called *[The House of Flowers](/wiki/House_of_Flowers_(mausoleum) "House of Flowers (mausoleum)")* , documents the life of the former Yugoslav president.^[\[227\]](#cite_note-230)^{#cite_ref-230}

[Ada Ciganlija](/wiki/Ada_Ciganlija "Ada Ciganlija") is a former island on the [Sava River](/wiki/Sava "Sava"), and Belgrade's biggest sports and recreational complex. Today it is connected with the right bank of the Sava via two causeways, creating an artificial lake. It is the most popular destination for Belgraders during the city's hot summers. There are 7 km (4 mi) of long beaches and sports facilities for various sports including golf, [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football"), basketball, volleyball, [rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union"), baseball, and tennis.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-tourist_organization_of_belgrade-231)^ During summer there are between 200,000 and 300,000 bathers daily.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-232)^{#cite_ref-232}

Belgrade is also known for tourist activities involving extreme sports such as [bungee jumping](/wiki/Bungee_jumping "Bungee jumping"), [water skiing](/wiki/Water_skiing "Water skiing"), and [paintballing](/wiki/Paintball "Paintball").^[\[228\]](#cite_note-tourist_organization_of_belgrade-231)^^[\[230\]](#cite_note-sport_activities_in_belgrade-233)^ There are numerous trails on the island, where it is possible to ride a bike, go for a walk, or go jogging.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-tourist_organization_of_belgrade-231)^^[\[230\]](#cite_note-sport_activities_in_belgrade-233)^ Apart from Ada, Belgrade has total of 16 islands^[\[231\]](#cite_note-234)^ on the rivers, many still unused. Among them, the [Great War Island](/wiki/Great_War_Island "Great War Island"), at the confluence of Sava, stands out as an oasis of unshattered wildlife (especially birds).^[\[232\]](#cite_note-235)^ These areas, along with nearby [Small War Island](/wiki/Small_War_Island "Small War Island"), are protected by the city's government as a [nature preserve](/wiki/Nature_preserve "Nature preserve").^[\[233\]](#cite_note-236)^ There are [37 protected natural resources](/wiki/List_of_natural_monuments_in_Belgrade "List of natural monuments in Belgrade") in the Belgrade urban area, among which eight are geo-heritage sites, i.e. [Straževica](/wiki/Stra%C5%BEevica "Straževica") profile, Mašin Majdan-[Topčider](/wiki/Top%C4%8Dider "Topčider"), Profile at the [Kalemegdan Fortress](/wiki/Kalemegdan_Fortress "Kalemegdan Fortress"), Abandoned quarry in [Barajevo](/wiki/Barajevo "Barajevo"), Karagača valley, Artesian well in [Ovča](/wiki/Ov%C4%8Da "Ovča"), Kapela [loess](/wiki/Loess "Loess") profile, and Lake in [Sremčica](/wiki/Srem%C4%8Dica "Sremčica"). Other 29 places are biodiversity sites.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-237)^{#cite_ref-237}

Tourist income in 2016 amounted to nearly half a billion [euros](/wiki/Euro "Euro");^[\[235\]](#cite_note-238)^ with a visit of almost a million registered tourists.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-vestionlinecom-239)^ Of those, in 2019 more than 100,000 tourists arrived by 742 river cruisers.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-vestionlinecom-239)^^[\[237\]](#cite_note-240)^ Average annual growth is between 13% and 14%.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-vestionlinecom-239)^{#cite_ref-vestionlinecom_239-2}

As of 2018, there are three officially designated [camp grounds](/wiki/Camp_grounds "Camp grounds") in Belgrade. The oldest one is located in [Batajnica](/wiki/Batajnica "Batajnica"), along the Batajnica Road. Named "Dunav", it is one of the most visited campsites in the country. The second one is situated within the complex of the ethno-household "Zornić's House" in the village of [Baćevac](/wiki/Ba%C4%87evac "Baćevac"), while the third is located in [Ripanj](/wiki/Ripanj "Ripanj"), on the slopes of Avala mountain. In 2017 some 15,000 overnights were recorded in camps.^[\[238\]](#cite_note-241)^{#cite_ref-241}

Belgrade is a common stop on the [Rivers Route](/wiki/EV6_The_Rivers_Route "EV6 The Rivers Route"), European [cycling route](/wiki/Long-distance_cycling_route "Long-distance cycling route") known as "Danube Bike Trail" in Serbia as well as on the [Sultans Trail](/wiki/Sultans_Trail "Sultans Trail"), a long-distance hiking footpath between [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") and [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul").  

### Nightlife {#Nightlife}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Nightlife")\]  
Main article: [Nightlife in Belgrade](/wiki/Nightlife_in_Belgrade "Nightlife in Belgrade")

Belgrade has a reputation for vibrant nightlife; many [clubs](/wiki/Nightclub "Nightclub") that are open until dawn can be found throughout the city.^[\[239\]](#cite_note-242)^ The most recognisable nightlife features of Belgrade are the barges (*splav* ) spread along the banks of the Sava and Danube Rivers.^[\[240\]](#cite_note-243)^^[\[241\]](#cite_note-244)^^[\[242\]](#cite_note-245)^{#cite_ref-245}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Belgrade_nightlife_on_riverclubs.jpg/220px-Belgrade_nightlife_on_riverclubs.jpg)](/wiki/File:Belgrade_nightlife_on_riverclubs.jpg) Belgrade nightlife [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/63oGrad.jpg/220px-63oGrad.jpg)](/wiki/File:63oGrad.jpg) Belgrade night aerial view

Many weekend visitors---particularly from [Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina"), [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia") and [Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia "Slovenia")---prefer Belgrade nightlife to that of their own capitals due to its perceived friendly atmosphere, plentiful clubs and bars, cheap drinks, lack of significant language barriers, and a lack of night life regulation.^[\[243\]](#cite_note-246)^^[\[244\]](#cite_note-247)^ One of the most famous sites for alternative cultural happenings in the city is the SKC (Student Cultural Centre), located right across from Belgrade's highrise landmark, the [Belgrade Palace tower](/wiki/Beogra%C4%91anka "Beograđanka"). Concerts featuring famous local and foreign bands are often held at the centre. SKC is also the site of various art exhibitions, as well as public debates and discussions.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-248)^{#cite_ref-248}

A more traditional Serbian nightlife experience, accompanied by traditional music known as *[Starogradska](/wiki/Starogradska_muzika "Starogradska muzika")* (roughly translated as *Old Town Music* ), typical of northern Serbia's urban environments, is most prominent in [Skadarlija](/wiki/Skadarlija "Skadarlija"), the city's old [bohemian](/wiki/Bohemianism "Bohemianism") neighbourhood where the poets and artists of Belgrade gathered in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Skadar Street (the centre of Skadarlija) and the surrounding neighbourhood are lined with some of Belgrade's best and oldest traditional restaurants (called [kafanas](/wiki/Kafana "Kafana") in Serbian), which date back to that period.^[\[246\]](#cite_note-249)^ At one end of the neighbourhood stands Belgrade's oldest beer brewery, founded in the first half of the 19th century.^[\[247\]](#cite_note-250)^ One of the city's oldest kafanas is the [Znak pitanja](/wiki/Znak_pitanja "Znak pitanja") ('?').^[\[248\]](#cite_note-251)^{#cite_ref-251}

*[The Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times")* reported that Europe's best nightlife can be found in Belgrade.^[\[249\]](#cite_note-252)^ In the [Lonely Planet](/wiki/Lonely_Planet "Lonely Planet") *1000 Ultimate Experiences* Guide of 2009, Belgrade was placed at the 1st spot among the top 10 party cities in the world.^[\[250\]](#cite_note-253)^{#cite_ref-253}  

### Fashion and design {#Fashion_and_design}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Fashion and design")\]

Since 1996,^[\[251\]](#cite_note-254)^ semiannual (autumn/winter and spring/summer seasons) [fashion weeks](/wiki/Fashion_week "Fashion week") are held citywide. Numerous Serbian and foreign designers and fashion brands have their shows during [Belgrade Fashion Week](/wiki/Belgrade_Fashion_Week "Belgrade Fashion Week"). The festival, which collaborates with [London Fashion Week](/wiki/London_Fashion_Week "London Fashion Week"), has helped launch the international careers of local talents such as [George Styler](/wiki/George_Styler "George Styler") and [Ana Ljubinković](/wiki/Ana_Ljubinkovi%C4%87 "Ana Ljubinković"). British fashion designer [Roksanda Ilinčić](/wiki/Roksanda_Ilin%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Roksanda Ilinčić"), who was born in the city, also frequently presents her runway shows in Belgrade.{#cite_ref-254}

In addition to fashion, there are two major design shows held in Belgrade every year which attract international architects and industrial designers such as [Karim Rashid](/wiki/Karim_Rashid "Karim Rashid"), [Daniel Libeskind](/wiki/Daniel_Libeskind "Daniel Libeskind"), [Patricia Urquiola](/wiki/Patricia_Urquiola "Patricia Urquiola"), and [Konstantin Grcic](/wiki/Konstantin_Grcic "Konstantin Grcic"). Both the [Mikser Festival](/wiki/Mikser_Festival "Mikser Festival") and [Belgrade Design Week](/wiki/Belgrade_Design_Week "Belgrade Design Week") feature lectures, exhibits and competitions. Furthermore, international designers like [Sacha Lakic](/wiki/Sacha_Lakic "Sacha Lakic"), [Ana Kraš](/wiki/Ana_Kra%C5%A1 "Ana Kraš"), [Bojana Sentaler](/wiki/Bojana_Sentaler "Bojana Sentaler"), and [Marek Djordjevic](/wiki/Marek_Djordjevic "Marek Djordjevic") are originally from Belgrade.  

Media {#Media}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Media")\]  
See also: [List of media organisations in Belgrade](/wiki/List_of_media_organisations_in_Belgrade "List of media organisations in Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Digital_Belgrade%2C_Tanjug%2C_01.jpg/220px-Digital_Belgrade%2C_Tanjug%2C_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Digital_Belgrade,_Tanjug,_01.jpg) [Tanjug](/wiki/Tanjug "Tanjug"), the former Serbian state-owned news agency building, defunct in 2021

Belgrade is the most important media hub in Serbia. The city is home to the main headquarters of the national broadcaster [Radio Television Serbia (RTS)](/wiki/Radio_Television_of_Serbia "Radio Television of Serbia"), which is a public service broadcaster.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-255)^ The most popular commercial broadcaster is [RTV Pink](/wiki/RTV_Pink "RTV Pink"), a Serbian media multinational, known for its popular entertainment programmes. One of the most popular commercial broadcasters is [B92](/wiki/B92 "B92"), another media company, which has its own TV station, radio station, and music and book publishing arms, as well as the most popular website on the Serbian internet.^[\[253\]](#cite_note-256)^^[\[254\]](#cite_note-257)^ Other TV stations broadcasting from Belgrade include [1Prva](/wiki/Prva_Srpska_Televizija "Prva Srpska Televizija") (formerly *Fox televizija* ), [Nova](/wiki/Nova.rs "Nova.rs"), [N1](/wiki/N1_(television) "N1 (television)") and others which only cover the greater Belgrade municipal area, such as [Studio B](/wiki/RTV_Studio_B "RTV Studio B").{#cite_ref-257}

High-circulation daily newspapers published in Belgrade include *[Politika](/wiki/Politika "Politika")*, *[Blic](/wiki/Blic "Blic")* , *[Alo!](/wiki/Alo! "Alo!")* , *[Kurir](/wiki/Kurir "Kurir")* and *[Danas](/wiki/Danas_(newspaper) "Danas (newspaper)")* . There are two sporting dailies, *[Sportski žurnal](/wiki/Sportski_%C5%BEurnal "Sportski žurnal")* and *[Sport](/wiki/DSL_Sport "DSL Sport")* , and one economic daily, *[Privredni pregled](/w/index.php?title=Privredni_pregled&action=edit&redlink=1 "Privredni pregled (page does not exist)")* . A new free distribution daily, *[24 sata](/wiki/24_sata_(Serbia) "24 sata (Serbia)")* , was founded in the autumn of 2006. Also, Serbian editions of licensed magazines such as *[Harper's Bazaar](/wiki/Harper%27s_Bazaar "Harper's Bazaar")* , *[Elle](/wiki/Elle_(magazine) "Elle (magazine)")* , *[Cosmopolitan](/wiki/Cosmopolitan_Serbia "Cosmopolitan Serbia")* , *[National Geographic](/wiki/National_Geographic_(magazine) "National Geographic (magazine)")* , *[Men's Health](/wiki/Men%27s_Health "Men's Health")* , *[Grazia](/wiki/Grazia "Grazia")* and others have their headquarters in the city.  

Sport and recreation {#Sport_and_recreation}
--------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Sport and recreation")\]  
See also: [List of sporting events in Belgrade](/wiki/List_of_sporting_events_in_Belgrade "List of sporting events in Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Ada_Ciganlija_lake.jpg/220px-Ada_Ciganlija_lake.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ada_Ciganlija_lake.jpg) [Ada Ciganlija](/wiki/Ada_Ciganlija "Ada Ciganlija")

There are approximately one-thousand sports facilities in Belgrade, many of which are capable of serving all levels of sporting events.^[\[255\]](#cite_note-258)^{#cite_ref-258}

[Ada Ciganlija](/wiki/Ada_Ciganlija "Ada Ciganlija") island, with its lake and beaches, is one of the most important recreational areas in the city. With a total of 8 km beaches, and a variety of bars, cafés, restaurants and sport facilities, Ada Ciganlija attracts many visitors, especially in summertime.

[Košutnjak](/wiki/Ko%C5%A1utnjak "Košutnjak") Park Forest has numerous running and bike trails, sports facilities for a variety of sports, and indoor and outdoor pools. It is a popular destination that is located only 2 km from Ada Ciganlija.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Fk_Red_Star_stadium.jpg/220px-Fk_Red_Star_stadium.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fk_Red_Star_stadium.jpg) [Rajko Mitić Stadium](/wiki/Red_Star_Stadium "Red Star Stadium") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Belgrade_Arena_%28SER%29.jpg/220px-Belgrade_Arena_%28SER%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Belgrade_Arena_(SER).jpg) [Belgrade Arena](/wiki/Belgrade_Arena "Belgrade Arena")

During the 1960s and 1970s Belgrade held a number of major international events such as the first ever World Aquatics Championships in [1973](/wiki/1973_World_Aquatics_Championships "1973 World Aquatics Championships"), [1976 European Football Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1976 "UEFA Euro 1976") and [1973 European Cup Final](/wiki/1972%E2%80%9373_European_Cup "1972–73 European Cup"), European Athletics Championships in [1962](/wiki/1962_European_Athletics_Championships "1962 European Athletics Championships") and [European Indoor Games](/wiki/European_Athletics_Indoor_Championships "European Athletics Indoor Championships") in 1969, European Basketball Championships in [1961](/wiki/EuroBasket_1961 "EuroBasket 1961") and [1975](/wiki/EuroBasket_1975 "EuroBasket 1975"), European Volleyball Championship for [men](/wiki/1975_Men%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship "1975 Men's European Volleyball Championship") and [women](/wiki/1975_Women%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship "1975 Women's European Volleyball Championship") in 1975 and World Amateur Boxing Championships in [1978](/wiki/1978_World_Amateur_Boxing_Championships "1978 World Amateur Boxing Championships").

Since the early 2000s Belgrade again hosts major sporting events nearly every year. Some of these include [EuroBasket 2005](/wiki/EuroBasket_2005 "EuroBasket 2005"), European Handball Championship ([men's](/wiki/2012_European_Men%27s_Handball_Championship "2012 European Men's Handball Championship") and [women's](/wiki/2012_European_Women%27s_Handball_Championship "2012 European Women's Handball Championship")) in 2012, [World Handball Championship](/wiki/2013_World_Women%27s_Handball_Championship "2013 World Women's Handball Championship") for women in 2013, European Volleyball Championships for men in [2005](/wiki/2005_European_Volleyball_Championship "2005 European Volleyball Championship") for men and [2011](/wiki/2011_Women%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship "2011 Women's European Volleyball Championship") for women, the 2006 and 2016 [European Water Polo Championship](/wiki/European_Water_Polo_Championship "European Water Polo Championship"), the [European Youth Olympic Festival](/wiki/European_Youth_Olympic_Festival "European Youth Olympic Festival") 2007 and the [2009 Summer Universiade](/wiki/Universiade "Universiade").^[\[256\]](#cite_note-259)^ More recently, Belgrade hosted [European Athletics Indoor Championships](/wiki/European_Athletics_Indoor_Championships "European Athletics Indoor Championships") in 2017 and the basketball [EuroLeague Final Four](/wiki/EuroLeague_Final_Four "EuroLeague Final Four") tournaments in 2018 and 2022. Global and continental championships in other sports such as [tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis"), [futsal](/wiki/Futsal "Futsal"), [judo](/wiki/Judo "Judo"), [karate](/wiki/Karate "Karate"), [wrestling](/wiki/Wrestling "Wrestling"), [rowing](/wiki/Rowing_(sport) "Rowing (sport)"), [kickboxing](/wiki/Kickboxing "Kickboxing"), [table tennis](/wiki/Table_tennis "Table tennis"), and [chess](/wiki/Chess "Chess") have also been held in recent years.{#cite_ref-259}

The city is home to Serbia's two biggest and most successful [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") clubs, [Red Star Belgrade](/wiki/Red_Star_Belgrade "Red Star Belgrade") and [Partizan Belgrade](/wiki/FK_Partizan "FK Partizan"). Red Star won the [UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") (*European Cup* ) in [1991](/wiki/1990%E2%80%9391_European_Cup "1990–91 European Cup"), and Partizan was runner-up in [1966](/wiki/1965%E2%80%9366_European_Cup "1965–66 European Cup"). The two major stadiums in Belgrade are *Marakana* ([Red Star Stadium](/wiki/Red_Star_Stadium "Red Star Stadium")) and [Partizan Stadium](/wiki/Partizan_Stadium "Partizan Stadium").^[\[257\]](#cite_note-260)^ The [Eternal derby](/wiki/Eternal_derby_(Serbia) "Eternal derby (Serbia)") is between Red Star and Partizan.{#cite_ref-260}

With a capacity of 19,384 spectators,[Belgrade Arena](/wiki/Belgrade_Arena "Belgrade Arena") is one of the largest indoor arenas in Europe.^[\[258\]](#cite_note-261)^ It is used for major sporting events and large concerts. In May 2008, it was the venue for the [53rd Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2008 "Eurovision Song Contest 2008").^[\[259\]](#cite_note-262)^[Aleksandar Nikolić Hall](/wiki/Aleksandar_Nikoli%C4%87_Hall "Aleksandar Nikolić Hall") is the main venue of [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") clubs [KK Partizan](/wiki/KK_Partizan "KK Partizan"), the European champion of 1992, and [KK Crvena Zvezda](/wiki/KK_Crvena_Zvezda "KK Crvena Zvezda").^[\[260\]](#cite_note-263)^^[\[261\]](#cite_note-264)^ In recent years, Belgrade has also given rise to several world-class tennis players such as [Ana Ivanovic](/wiki/Ana_Ivanovic "Ana Ivanovic"), [Jelena Janković](/wiki/Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87 "Jelena Janković") and [Novak Djokovic](/wiki/Novak_Djokovic "Novak Djokovic"). Ivanovic and Djokovic are the first female and male Belgraders, respectively, to win [Grand Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis) "Grand Slam (tennis)") singles titles and been [ATP number 1](/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players") with [Jelena Janković](/wiki/Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87 "Jelena Janković"). The Serbian national team won the [2010 Davis Cup](/wiki/2010_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2010 Davis Cup World Group"), beating the French team in the finals played in the [Belgrade Arena](/wiki/Belgrade_Arena "Belgrade Arena").^[\[262\]](#cite_note-265)^{#cite_ref-265}

The [Belgrade Marathon](/wiki/Belgrade_Marathon "Belgrade Marathon") is held annually since 1988. Belgrade was a candidate to host the 1992 and the 1996 [Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games").^[\[263\]](#cite_note-266)^^[\[264\]](#cite_note-267)^{#cite_ref-267}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Education")\]  
See also: [List of educational institutions in Belgrade](/wiki/List_of_educational_institutions_in_Belgrade "List of educational institutions in Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Kapetan_Misino_Zdanje_zgrada.JPG/200px-Kapetan_Misino_Zdanje_zgrada.JPG)](/wiki/File:Kapetan_Misino_Zdanje_zgrada.JPG) [Administration Building of the University of Belgrade](/wiki/Captain_Mi%C5%A1a%27s_Mansion "Captain Miša's Mansion")

Belgrade has two state universities and several private institutions of higher education. The [University of Belgrade](/wiki/University_of_Belgrade "University of Belgrade"), founded in 1808 as a [*grande école*](/wiki/Grandes_%C3%A9coles "Grandes écoles"), is the oldest institution of higher learning in Serbia.^[\[265\]](#cite_note-268)^ Having developed with much of the rest of the city in the 19th century, several university buildings are recognised as forming a constituent part of Belgrade's architecture and [cultural heritage](/wiki/Cultural_heritage "Cultural heritage"). With enrolment numbers of nearly 90,000 students, the university is one of Europe's largest.^[\[266\]](#cite_note-269)^{#cite_ref-269}

The city is also home to 195 primary (elementary) schools and 85 secondary schools. The primary school system has 162 regular schools, 14 [special](/wiki/Special_education "Special education") schools, 15 art schools, and 4 adult schools, while the secondary school system has 51 vocational schools, 21 [gymnasiums](/wiki/Gymnasium_(school) "Gymnasium (school)"), 8 art schools and 5 special schools. The 230,000 pupils are managed by 22,000 employees in over 500 buildings, covering around 1.1×10\^^6^ m^2^ (12×10\^^6^ sq ft).^[\[267\]](#cite_note-270)^{#cite_ref-270}  

Transportation {#Transportation}
--------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Transportation")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Belgrade](/wiki/Transport_in_Belgrade "Transport in Belgrade")  
See also: [Trams in Belgrade](/wiki/Trams_in_Belgrade "Trams in Belgrade") and [Bridges in Belgrade](/wiki/Bridges_in_Belgrade "Bridges in Belgrade")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%98%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BF%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%B6%D0%B5%D1%99%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%BA%D0%B5_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5_%D0%91%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D1%86%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%807.jpg/220px-%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%98%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BF%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%B6%D0%B5%D1%99%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%BA%D0%B5_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5_%D0%91%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D1%86%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%807.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%98%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BF%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%B6%D0%B5%D1%99%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%BA%D0%B5_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5_%D0%91%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D1%86%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%807.jpg) [Belgrade Centre Railway Station](/wiki/Belgrade_Centre_Railway_Station "Belgrade Centre Railway Station") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/CAF_%26_KT4_Tram_Belgrade.jpg/220px-CAF_%26_KT4_Tram_Belgrade.jpg)](/wiki/File:CAF_%26_KT4_Tram_Belgrade.jpg) [Trams in Belgrade](/wiki/Trams_in_Belgrade "Trams in Belgrade") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/GSP_Logo.svg/220px-GSP_Logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:GSP_Logo.svg) The logo for the company

Belgrade has an extensive public transport system consisting of buses (118 urban lines and more than 300 suburban lines), trams (12 lines), [trolleybuses](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus") (8 lines) and [S-Train](/wiki/S-Train "S-Train") [BG Voz](/wiki/BG_Voz "BG Voz") (6 lines).^[\[268\]](#cite_note-271)^^[\[269\]](#cite_note-272)^ Buses, trolleybuses and trams are run by [GSP Beograd](/wiki/GSP_Beograd "GSP Beograd") and [SP Lasta](/wiki/Lasta_Beograd "Lasta Beograd") in cooperation with private companies on some bus routes. The [S-train](/wiki/S-train "S-train") network, [BG Voz](/wiki/BG_Voz "BG Voz"), run by city government in cooperation with [Serbian Railways](/wiki/Serbian_Railways "Serbian Railways"), is a part of the integrated transport system, and has three lines (Batajnica-Ovča and Ovča-Resnik and Belgrade centre-Mladenovac), with more announced.^[\[270\]](#cite_note-273)^^[\[271\]](#cite_note-274)^ As of 27 February 2024^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Belgrade&action=edit)^ tickets may be purchased either via SMS or in physical paper form via the *Beograd plus* / Београд плус system.^[\[272\]](#cite_note-275)^ Daily connections link the capital to other towns in Serbia and many other European destinations through the city's [central bus station](/wiki/Belgrade_Bus_Station "Belgrade Bus Station"). Since January 2025 all public transport in Belgrade is free.^[\[273\]](#cite_note-276)^{#cite_ref-276}

[Beovoz](/wiki/Beovoz "Beovoz") was the [suburban/commuter railway](/wiki/Regional_rail "Regional rail") network that provided [mass-transit](/wiki/Mass-transit "Mass-transit") services in the city, similar to Paris's [RER](/wiki/R%C3%A9seau_Express_R%C3%A9gional "Réseau Express Régional") and Toronto's [GO Transit](/wiki/GO_Transit "GO Transit"). The main usage of system was to connect the suburbs with the city centre. Beovoz was operated by [Serbian Railways](/wiki/Serbian_Railways "Serbian Railways").^[\[274\]](#cite_note-277)^ However, this system was abolished back in 2013, mostly due to introduction of more efficient BG Voz. Belgrade is one of the last big European capitals and cities with over a million people to have no metro or subway or other [rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") system. As of November 2021, the [Belgrade Metro](/wiki/Belgrade_Metro "Belgrade Metro") is currently under construction, which will have 2 lines. The first line is expected to be operational by August 2028.^[\[275\]](#cite_note-278)^^[\[276\]](#cite_note-279)^{#cite_ref-279}

The new [Belgrade Centre railway station](/wiki/Belgrade_Centre_railway_station "Belgrade Centre railway station") is the hub for almost all national and international trains. The [high-speed rail](/wiki/High-speed_rail "High-speed rail") that connects Belgrade with [Novi Sad](/wiki/Novi_Sad "Novi Sad") started its service on 19 March 2022.^[\[277\]](#cite_note-280)^ The extension towards [Subotica](/wiki/Subotica "Subotica") and [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest") is under construction,^[\[278\]](#cite_note-281)^ and there are plans for a southwards extension towards [Niš](/wiki/Ni%C5%A1 "Niš") and [North Macedonia](/wiki/North_Macedonia "North Macedonia").^[\[279\]](#cite_note-282)^{#cite_ref-282}

The city is placed along the [Pan-European corridors](/wiki/Pan-European_corridors "Pan-European corridors") [X](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_X "Pan-European Corridor X") and VII.^[\[10\]](#cite_note-city_of_belgrade-2-12)^ The motorway system provides for easy access to [Novi Sad](/wiki/Novi_Sad "Novi Sad") and [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest") to the north, [Niš](/wiki/Ni%C5%A1 "Niš") to the south, and [Zagreb](/wiki/Zagreb "Zagreb") to the west. Expressway is also toward Pančevo and new Expressway construction toward Obrenovac (Montenegro) is scheduled for March 2017. [Belgrade bypass](/wiki/Belgrade_bypass "Belgrade bypass") is connecting the [E70](/wiki/E70_in_Serbia "E70 in Serbia") and [E75](/wiki/E75_in_Serbia "E75 in Serbia") motorways and is under construction.^[\[280\]](#cite_note-283)^{#cite_ref-283}

Situated at the confluence of two major rivers, the Danube and the Sava, Belgrade has 11 bridges, the most important of which are [Branko's Bridge,](/wiki/Branko%27s_Bridge "Branko's Bridge") [Gazela Bridge](/wiki/Gazela_Bridge "Gazela Bridge"), [Ada Bridge](/wiki/Ada_Bridge "Ada Bridge") and [Pupin Bridge](/wiki/Pupin_Bridge "Pupin Bridge"), the first two of which connect the core of the city to [New Belgrade](/wiki/New_Belgrade "New Belgrade"). In addition, an 'inner magistral semi-ring' is almost done and includes a new Ada bridge across the Sava river (opened in 2012)^[\[281\]](#cite_note-284)^ and a new Pupin bridge (opened in 2014)^[\[282\]](#cite_note-285)^ across the Danube river, which ease [commuting](/wiki/Commuting "Commuting") within the city and unload traffic from the Gazela Bridge and Branko's Bridge.^[\[283\]](#cite_note-286)^{#cite_ref-286}

The [Port of Belgrade](/wiki/Port_of_Belgrade "Port of Belgrade") is on the Danube, and allows the city to receive goods by river.^[\[284\]](#cite_note-287)^ The city is also served by [Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport](/wiki/Belgrade_Nikola_Tesla_Airport "Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport"), 12 km (7.5 mi) west of the city centre, near [Surčin](/wiki/Sur%C4%8Din "Surčin"). At its peak in 1986, almost 3 million passengers travelled through the airport, though that number dwindled to a trickle in the 1990s.^[\[285\]](#cite_note-288)^ Following renewed growth in 2000, the number of passengers reached approximately 2 million in 2004 and 2005,^[\[286\]](#cite_note-289)^ over 2.6 million passengers in 2008,^[\[287\]](#cite_note-290)^ reaching over 3 million passengers.^[\[288\]](#cite_note-291)^ A record with over 4 million passengers was broken in 2014, when Belgrade [Nikola Tesla Airport](/wiki/Nikola_Tesla_Airport "Nikola Tesla Airport") became the second fastest growing major airport in Europe.^[\[289\]](#cite_note-292)^ The numbers continued to grow steadily and the all-time peak of over 6 million passengers was reached in 2019.^[\[290\]](#cite_note-293)^{#cite_ref-293}

Belgrade has received various domestic and international honours, including the French [Légion d'honneur](/wiki/L%C3%A9gion_d%27honneur "Légion d'honneur") (proclaimed 21 December 1920; Belgrade is one of four cities outside France, alongside [Liège](/wiki/Li%C3%A8ge "Liège"), [Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg_City "Luxembourg City") and [Volgograd](/wiki/Volgograd "Volgograd"), to receive this honour), the [Czechoslovak War Cross](/wiki/Czechoslovak_War_Cross_1918 "Czechoslovak War Cross 1918") (awarded 8 October 1925), the Yugoslavian [Order of the Karađorđe's Star](/wiki/Order_of_the_Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e%27s_Star "Order of the Karađorđe's Star") (awarded 18 May 1939) and the Yugoslavian [Order of the People's Hero](/wiki/Order_of_the_People%27s_Hero "Order of the People's Hero") (proclaimed on 20 October 1974, the 30th anniversary of the overthrow of [Nazi German](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") occupation during World War II).^[\[304\]](#cite_note-307)^ All of these decorations were received for the war efforts during World War I and World War II.^[\[305\]](#cite_note-308)^ In 2006, *[Financial Times](/wiki/Financial_Times "Financial Times")'* magazine *[Foreign Direct Investment](/wiki/FDi_magazine "FDi magazine")* awarded Belgrade the title of *City of the Future of Southern Europe* .^[\[306\]](#cite_note-309)^^[\[307\]](#cite_note-310)^{#cite_ref-310}
